Indian Affairs Branch, Department Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

With reference to Departmental letter No. 121-8-5/121-6-5 (E1) dated July 26 last pertaining to desks for the new Indian Day Schools under construction at the Nut Lake and Poorman Reserves.

At the Nut Lake Reserve there are 79 children of school age of which 6 are enrolled with the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

At the Poorman Reserve there are 61 children of school age. Of these 34 are enrolled with the Muscowequan, and 11 with the Gordon Residential Schools. A number of the members of this reserve have stated that they want their children who have been attending residential school, admitted into the Day school as soon as it is opened. If their request is granted, it is anticipated that the Day school will be filled to capacity.

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Superintendent.
August 4, 1948.

Mr. S.H. Simpson, Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

With reference to your letter of the 29th ultimo, we have ordered the desks for both the Nut Lake and Poorman Schools.

With reference to the last paragraph of your letter, very careful consideration should be given before withdrawing the children from the residential schools and placing them in the day schools.

You should carefully investigate home conditions to decide the number of children who actually require institutional care. You should also assure yourself that the children who are withdrawn from residential schools to attend day schools will attend regularly. It will not be of any advantage to all parties concerned if the children are just taken from the residential schools and the parents are not in a position or have not the inclination to make certain that they attend school every day except in the case of very severe illness.

When you have reviewed the situation we would appreciate hearing from you.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Re: Your letter 982-312-11A
Painting new school, Nut Lake Reserve.

It has not been possible to locate Indian labourers who are capable of doing the paint job required at this school.

After considerable effort I have been able to procure a tender from J.W. Rusnell, painter, Wadena, Sask. to paint the interior and exterior of the school building, 3 coats, also the outside toilets for the sum of $350.00 labour only.

It is considered that his offer is most reasonable and I would recommend that it be given favourable consideration.

The paint for this work is on hand at Nut Lake Reserve and I would ask that authority be given as soon as possible to have this work completed.

Sgd. S.H. Simpson,

Regina, August 27th, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

An effort has been made to have the labour of painting the new school house at the Nut Lake Reserve, of the Touchwood Agency, performed by Indians, but without success.

Mr. S.H. Simpson, Superintendent, Touchwood Agency, has a quotation from Mr. G.W. Russell, painter of Wadena, Saskatchewan, who agrees to perform all the labour of painting the interior and exterior of the building with three coats, also the outside toilets, for the sum of $350.00.

As this price is very reasonable, and the material is on hand for the purpose, I would recommend that Mr. Simpson be given authority to employ Mr. Russell at once for this work.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont

Re Nut Lake Indian Day School

On August 26th I sent a letter to Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Saskatchewan, in which it was advised that the children that will be attending this school be provided with a hot noon day meal during the winter and early spring months. An extra copy of that letter was sent to him which undoubtedly he will forward to Ottawa.

Attached hereto is Form 37 listing the articles that will be required for this purpose, also Form 37a listing the type of cook stove suitable to be installed in the basement of the school where the children will have their mid day meal prepared and served to them.

S.H. Simpson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing copy of a letter from Superintendent S. H. Simpson of the Touchwood Agency and two Requisitions; one for a 4 wheel trailer, $274.00, wagon box $80.00, bob sleigh $98.90, totaling $452.90; the other for labor and materials, $65.00, for the construction of a covered van with heater and seats. All necessary equipment in connection with the transportation of children to the Nut Lake Indian Day school.

The Indian homes on the Nut Lake reserve are widely scattered. The new school site is in that part of the reserve where the majority of the Indians will eventually live, because of its soil conditions, which make that part of the reserve more suitable for agriculture in the future. Farming has only commenced in earnest in the last two years and it will be some time before the majority of the Indians are located on the part of the reserve adjacent to the school. In the meantime it will be necessary to provide transportation as recommended by Mr. Simpson in order to promote regular attendance.

I would recommend that Mr. Simpson be given authority to purchase the necessary transportation equipment locally, in accordance with the requisitions enclosed, and that the Department agree to the rate of .25¢ per day, per pupil, delivered at the school and returned to the pupils' homes in the evening.

I am writing Mr. Simpson regarding the matter of midday meal, and am enclosing a copy of this letter herewith.

J. P. B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies
Saskatchewan.
There are 78 children of school age on the Butte Lake Reserve, 14 of these live within a radius of 3 miles and 50 live from 2½ to 7 miles distant. The parents of 14 have no homes on the reserve and reside elsewhere. Of the 78 children 6 attend Residential school. It is considered that 7 of these should continue to attend there as their home conditions are not such as to assure proper care and attendance to the day school.

In order to have as many children as possible attend school it is considered necessary to provide transportation to and from school for them as in many cases their homes are too far distant for the children to walk. Vehicles will have to be provided for this purpose and a driver.

I recommend that an Indian be employed to do the driving and provide his own team of horses. It is suggested that he be paid at the rate of $25 per day per pupil delivered to and from the school rather than being paid a daily or monthly wage. It is felt that this method of payment would assure a better attendance at the school and prove more economical.

It is estimated that there will be about 25 children that can be counted on to attend the day school this winter.

Attached hereto is Form 37 listing rubber tired trailer, bobleigh and wagon box. Also Form 37 for materials to cover the wagon box and provide a heater and seats therein. This will be able to be used during summer or winter as it can be used on wheels or sleighs.

It is also considered necessary that the children be provided with a hot noon-day meal during the winter and early spring months.

Authority is requested to procure the materials and labour to cover the wagon at a total cost of $65.00, locally.

S.H. Simpson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency

Ottawa telegram to you, Aug 30/48
Painting Nut Lake Indian Day School.

On October 14th, I received a letter from Mr. G.W. Rusnell, who had been awarded the contract to paint this school, advising that he was unable to complete his contract as his hired help had left him and he was unable to procure anyone else. He has done the following work.

Roofs of school and toilets completed, the west, north and east walls of school, two coats. Three coats have been applied on inside windows of basement. One coat on all windows inside class room. One coat on outside walls and windows of toilets. Two coats on kitchen walls and ceiling. One coat on basement hallway. Three coats on walls and ceiling of classroom.

I am now in receipt of a tender from Messrs F.H. and Ben Olson of Kuroki, Sask. to complete the exterior painting of school and toilets for the sum of $100.00. Also to complete the interior painting of school building, including one coat on class room, which is considered that the three coats applied has not made a good finish. Also to paint all window frames, storm sashes and screens for the sum of $300.00, total $400.00.

I am also in receipt of a tender from Mr. S.O. Larson, Rose Valley, to do the exterior work already mentioned, for the sum of $100.00 and to do the interior painting, just mentioned, for the sum of $270.00, total $370.00.

Mr Gordon W Rusnell and his helper Mr. Welfin each did 7½ days work using spray and brush. His painting equipment had to be moved to and from the reserve to Wadena, a distance of 35 miles. The total cost of board was $27.00 and Mr. Rusnell estimates that the cost of moving the equipment was $53.00. He considers the work done is worth $150.00. In view of the amount tendered to complete the work as already referred to and a previous tender to do this work by Luthi Bros. of Punnichy amounting to $700.00 submitted to the Department by Agency letter of May 10/48. It appears that Mr.
Rusnell's value of the work done is reasonable.

It is considered too late in the year to do any exterior painting, I recommend that Mr. S.O. Larson be given the contract of completing the interior painting for the sum of $270.00.

Mr. Rusnell has requested advice as to whether or not he will be paid for the work done, namely $150.00.

I recommend that favorable consideration be given to paying him $150.00.

S.H. Simpson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency

With reference to Department Army Message dated August 30th, 1948, containing authority to accept the tender of Mr. G.W. Rusnell to paint the new day school at the Nut Lake Reserve, at a price of $350.00, I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter received from Superintendent S.H. Simpson, of the Touchwood Agency, in connection with this contract, recommending that Mr. Rusnell be paid the sum of $150.00 for the work which he has performed on the school, and that Mr. S.O. Larson be given the contract for completing the interior painting of the school for the sum of $270.00.

I discussed this matter with Mr. Simpson on a recent visit to the Nut Lake School, when I found that the work set out in Mr. Simpson's letter had been completed, and that Mr. Rusnell had ceased work and refused to continue after having found that he had quoted a price so low that he could not complete the work without still further loss.

I would recommend that Mr. Simpson's plan be followed and that Mr. Larson's offer be accepted, namely to complete the interior work at a total cost of $270.00, and $100.00 to complete the exterior work next spring. By paying Mr. Rusnell $150.00 and Mr. Larson $370.00, the total cost of the exterior and interior painting for the building will amount to $520.00 which, I believe, is a fair price for the whole job, and is $180.00 less than the quotation for the whole job submitted by Luthi Brothers, of Punnichy.

J.P.B. Ostrander,

Indian Affairs Branch, Department Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

re: Jut Lake Indian Day School

On August 30, 1948 a requisition was forwarded by Supt. Simpson listing articles required in the preparation of the noon day meal for the children. I am informed that all the articles have been received with the exception of the cook stove. In your letter of September 7, 1948, file 121-3-5 (E) acknowledging receipt of the requisition you suggested that the combination Quebec heater-range was being provided for other schools and would prove satisfactory. Apparently this latter stove has not been requisitioned for to date so I am enclosing herewith the required form 37.

On September 4th, 1948 a letter was forwarded to your office requesting authority to purchase food supplies locally for a hot mid-day meal, the total amount not to exceed $75.00 during the academic year. So far we have not received this authority. Would you please have this forwarded as soon as possible as we plan on opening the school on March 1st.

Apparently janitor supplies have not been requisitioned for. May I suggest that you authorize local purchase of the janitor supplies as you did for the Meadow Lake school where I was in charge during December. This proved satisfactory there. Please forward a list of the articles needed for the janitor work. I would suggest that a galvanized tank (45 gallons) be included as no provision has been made for water storage.

J.T. Warden,
Acting Indian Superintendent

24th February, 1949.

Mr. J.T. Warden,
A/Supt., Indian Agency,
Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant, the Department approves purchase of a combination Quebec heater at a cost of $59.95 for use at the Nut Lake School.

Please let us know the cost of the 45 gallon galvanized tank.

I presume you understand that it is not our policy to supply a complete lunch at noon. We only allow materials for a hot drink or soup, which is intended to supplement whatever food the children bring for lunch. In view of the payment of family allowance it is felt that practically all Indian families should be in a position to supply a lunch for the children at noon. I might add that we only supply materials for lunch during the cold weather, namely from 1st October to 31st March of the following year.

It is noted that you expect to open this school on 1st March, 1949, and consequently, the amount of $7.50 is authorized for that month for the purchase of midday lunch supplies.

You may purchase locally the supplies for the janitor.

PP/ST

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
Indian Affairs Branch, Department Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

January 30, 1948.

Mr. R. S. Davis, Indian Agent,
Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

Construction of One-room Day School and Attached Teacherage - Poorman Reserve.

We have now a stock of blueprints, specifications and bills of materials for our standard one-room day school and attached teacher's residence.

The Auditor General has insisted that, in future, the clauses of the Public Works Act with regard to advertising for tenders be adhered to. During the emergency war years, some variations from these regulations were permitted, but we are now required to advertise for tenders on construction of public buildings in excess of $5,000.00. Attached hereto please find a sample advertisement. It is our intention to advertise for tenders for the construction of the school on the Poorman Reserve in the near future. Therefore, we would request you to advise us:

(a) The names of the newspapers in or near your agency in which you would recommend that we advertise;

(b) Post offices and other government buildings in which we should display drawings, specifications, etc.

Naturally, your own office will be one in which we will display drawings, etc. If no tenders are received after advertising, you will be advised so that other means can be considered whereby the construction of this school can be carried out during the fiscal year 1928-49. These other means

...... involve
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

With reference to Department letter 121-6-5 (E) dated January 30th, 1948 regarding the building of a Day School and Teacherage at Poorman Reserve.

(a) The newspapers in which an Ad could be displayed are the Touchwood Times, Punnichy Saskatoon Star-Phoenix, Saskatoon.

(b) Post offices where drawings, specifications should be displayed are the post office in Saskatoon, Superintendent's office, Regina and Indian Office, Punnichy.

A small electric plant will have to be installed as we are not near the power line. The closest we are to one being in the neighbourhood of six miles.

Water is very hard to get on this reserve. I have dug wells with the boring machine which have not been satisfactory, and would recommend that a drilling machine be put to work and locate water before we start to build the school.

The location could be as near as possible to the Farming Instructor's house, so that the well could serve the school and the Farming Instructor.

R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent.

Poorman Indian Day School.

Reference your C-11 (121) of February 7.

We have recently had an opportunity of discussing the situation with regard to the above school with Mr. Ostrander. It has been suggested by him that Mr. Holterman might also be interested in constructing this school on a similar basis as the Nut Lake School. It is understood that Mr. Ostrander will discuss this proposal with you when he returns to Saskatchewan.

We could then arrange to forward such materials as are required as per the standard bill of materials forwarded you for the Nut Lake School. In fact, I could forward two copies of the bill of materials and you could delete the items not required or which can be provided for by your own sawmill and then forward the amended bill of materials here attached to a standard requisition form. This standard requisition form should read as follows:

"Materials required for the construction of a one room day school as per attached standard bill of materials".

Therefore, it would seem that the big problem in erecting this school will be the location of a proper site with an adequate supply of water. It is understood that the Farming Instructor's water supply is from a "dug-out" some 600 feet from his house. We would appreciate hearing from you with regard to a source of water for both the school and Farming Instructor's house. Is it possible to obtain tenders for using a drilling machine such as recommended in your letter.

Bernard F. Neary,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Poorman Indian Day School.

The above Indian day school is one which is included in our 1948-49 building programme. It is our intention to purchase all the necessary materials through the Departmental Purchasing Agent. It is understood that some of the lumber will probably come from a saw mill operated by the Indians of the nearby Nut Lake Reserve.

Mr. Indian Agent Davis has obtained a written tender for all labour on the building with the exception of the painting. This tender includes excavation, putting in forms and all cement work complete. It is in the amount of $4,800.00 and is attached hereto.

This firm is the same company whose tender for the nearby Nut Lake day school was accepted on April 1st, 1948. At that time we were advised that they were a very reputable firm and that they would carry out the work in a satisfactory manner. It was therefore, suggested that the same company be approached with regard to the Poorman day school. As a result, we have now received the attached tender.

You will note that this tender is for $4,800.,
whereas the Nut Lake tender was for only $4,000. This is due to the fact that the excavation, forms, etc., had already been completed at Nut Lake, whereas this has not been done at Poorman.

You will recall that labour costs on these standard one room schools with attached teacher's residence have varied between $5,300 and $6,300 when the work was done on a cost plus basis. Therefore, this tender of John Holterman & Son would seem to be fair and reasonable and is recommended for acceptance by the Minister.

(Chitek Lake Indian Day School)

With reference to your letter of the 31st ultimo, File No. 107-7-5, in connection with the above, I have delayed answering because it was my intention to endeavour to have Holterman Brothers erect the Chitek Lake Day School if we had not been successful in locating a water supply for the Poorman's Day School. However, Mr. J. T. Warden, Field Assistant, Regina Office, visited the Poorman's Reserve this week and located a satisfactory well at a central point on the reserve at a depth of 8 ft. Consequently it is proposed to have Holterman Brothers proceed with the Poorman's Day School as soon as they have completed the Nut Lake Day School.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Re Departmental letter #121-6-5 (El) May 21, 1948
Drilling well at site of Poorman Reserve School

On enquiry from a local resident living adjacent to the reserve, and who appears to be very familiar with the water problem in the whole of this area, it was found that in the odd case that an adequate supply of good water could be found at the depth of up to 14 feet. Several unsuccessful attempts had been made to drill deep wells some of which were well over 200 feet deep. The most satisfactory method employed in this area for water supply is the dugout and filter well combination.

A school site has been located with ideal surroundings for building, play grounds, and fair soil for a garden, all of which is naturally drained. The prospect for water appeared promising enough to have a shallow well dug on the north side of a small knoll. It is 3½ feet square, and 8 feet deep and has a depth of 2½ feet of clear water therein which to the taste appears to be good. It was not possible to deepen the well owing to the flow of water there into. Bailing tests showed that a supply of from 100 to 120 gallons per hour is now available. This supply flows through a wall of sharp sand. It is proposed to have a sand point driven below the frost level to assure a winter supply of water. If this source of supply proves inadequate a dug out and filter well can be installed near this site.

The site is fairly central and is located within a radius of 3 miles from the best agricultural land on the reserve. It is within the same radius of the majority of Indian family homes, the remainder of the homes with children of school age are within 3½ miles thereof.

This whole matter was gone into by Mr. J.T. Warden of our Regina office with me and it is felt that the question of an adequate water supply is assured from the new well, or in the event of its failure from the dugout with filter well.

It is recommended that the construction work of this school be proceeded with as soon as possible.

Authority is requested to pay Indian labour the sum of $16 for digging the well which has been cribbed and closed in by materials which were on hand. Authority is also requested to purchase a suitable pump and sand point from the first available source.

Simpson Indian Agent

To date copies of the following purchase orders have been received:

Mr. Lang has advised me that he has not received any order to supply any of the building materials for this school. He requests to be advised as soon as possible if he is to do so, as he will require from four to five weeks to procure certain supplies.

The Indians at Poorman Reserve have gathered the small rock that will be required and are to be engaged in hauling gravel, to take the place of crushed rock which is not available for this district, and sand. J.P.B. Ostrander Esq., Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Regina.

Re: New Day School, Poorman Reserve.

With reference to our discussion pertaining to kitchen cupboard space being allowed in the construction of this school I have to report as follows:

On September 22nd, I advised the Department that the type of dresser which the Reliance Lumber Company intended to supply would not meet our requirements, and recommended that a built-in cupboard similar to that installed in the new school at Nut Lake be provided at a cost of $185.00.

On September 29th, under file #121-6-5(31) the Department replied in part as follows:

"We feel that $50.00 should be enough to expend for this purpose and are not prepared to authorize any additional amount."

The tender from the Reliance Lumber Company called for a kitchen dresser. A copy of their letter dated September 20th explained this, also that they figured that this was a small kitchen wash stand.

A small kitchen wash stand will only provide a stand for a hand wash basin, with a refuse pail thereunder enclosed in a cupboard. Therefore no provision has been made for space to store cutlery, dishes, pots, pans and food supplies. Due to the small kitchen space it is considered that built-in cupboards similar to those installed in the Nut Lake School at a cost of $185.00 will meet the requirements.

Further consideration of this matter would be appreciated.

S.H. Simpson,
Superintendent.
Regina, October 20th, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter received from Superintendent S.H. Simpson, of the Touchwood Agency, in connection with the new day school being constructed on the Poorman's Reserve.

The matter referred to in Mr. Simpson's letter was discussed with the writer last week, and there is no doubt that it is a mistake to not supply the teacherage of this day school with a cupboard such as has been installed in the similar teacherage which is part of the new school building at the Nut Lake Reserve.

I consider the cupboard arrangement at the Nut Lake building is very appropriate and convenient. This arrangement is very necessary in view of the fact that the kitchen is quite small, and there is no place where pots, pans, dishes, etc. can be stored.

To supply a school kitchen wash stand such as that on which the Reliance Lumber Company seems to have tendered, will provide entirely inadequate space for cooking utensils and dishes. It is my opinion that unless a cupboard is supplied, such as the one in the building on the Nut Lake Reserve, the kitchen will always be unsanitary, and certainly not a good example to the Indians who are much too prone to carelessness, hanging kitchen utensils all over the kitchen walls or piling them in a corner of the room.

I would strongly recommend that Mr. Simpson be given authority to install cupboards similar to those in the Nut Lake School, at a cost of $185.00, instead of the poor installation which will result from the expenditure of $60.00 which has been authorized by Department letter of September 9th, 1948, File 121-8-5 (E.1).

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Kitchen dresser, Pocman Indian Day School.

I have interviewed Messrs Holterman & Son, contractors regarding this matter, and have been advised that no materials have been supplied for this purpose, or included in the purchase orders pertaining to the construction of this building. Also that their contract only covers the installing of the kitchen dresser.

In the copy of the bill of material for standard combined one class room Indian Day School with Teacher's quarters, in part reads "NOTE: Stairs and kitchen dresser may be supplied pre-fabricated or in knock down form as required to meet conditions and as instructed by Officer in charge."

There does not appear to be any provision made to supply materials for the construction of cupboards in the class room for stationery and books.

Attached hereto is Form 37 listing the materials and labour to construct a kitchen cupboard the same as that now installed in the Nut Lake new day school. Owing to the shortage of material last fall, then cold weather setting in, the above contractors were unable to complete the ration houses on the Poorman and Muscowequan Reserves, nor the outdoor toilets for the Poorman Indian Day School.

In the case of the Poorman ration house the siding has to be put on and the second floor laid. The sum of $425.00 has been held back on the contract to complete the job. The work could have been done this month on this building had the lumber been dry but we think it advisable to wait until April.

Office of the Commissioner of Indian Affairs,
North-West Territories,
Regina, 24th November, 1887.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant, stating that His Lordship, Bishop Grandin, has informed the Department, that there is much need for the establishment of an Indian School at Lake la Prairie; and requesting, prior to taking any steps in the matter, to have a report relative to the number of children of school-age there, and whether or not the Indians will build the walls of the school-house, as is required of the Indians in other localities, on the understanding that the Department will grant $100 towards finishing the building.

In reply, I beg to inform

The Hon. you
The Supt. General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
you that the Indians in question were rebels, and have therefore not been paid since 1884; but in that year, fourteen boys and eighteen girls were paid for, although these numbers, in all probability, include considerably more than children of school-age.

Mr. ex-Agent Rae has been referred to, for his opinion, and gives it to be, that more than eight or ten Indian children could not be induced to attend.

In this case, he thinks that much extra expense, in feeding the Indians, would be incurred; since were their habits as hunters to be interrupted, they would require to be supported by the Department almost entirely; but with this, I do not quite agree.

With regard to their building the walls of a school-house, it is thought that they might probably be induced to do so, as in other cases.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant

My dear Sir,

I have just made a trip to Isle à la Croix, and in passing here, I at last decided to yield to the desire of Chief Francis Little Bear, of Prairie Lake, who for three years back, has been urging me to let him have a school and mission.

I have given a contract for the construction of a school, and have engaged as teacher Mr. Paul Greffaud, whom I know personally as being very capable of teaching, as well in French as in English.

He is married, and his wife, a young half-breed, is herself sufficiently educated to teach.

It being impossible to have the schoolhouse finished before the month of June, it will be necessary to keep school during the whole winter in a private house. There is no equipment; I hope...
hope that you will be kind enough to procure the necessaries for this purpose.

Although the Indians may not be very numerous at Prairie Lake, there are more than twenty children of school age. Paul Grand has been engaged at a salary of $300 per annum, and I have assured him that the Government would pay him faithfully.

I find here letters from Battleford, and learn with equal sorrow and surprise that they continue to refuse to recognize the Catholic school entrusted to Father Vachon, on Thunder Child's Reserve.

I am all the more surprised at the difficulties which they make, since on the reserves of Prairie Assiniboine and Onion Lake, where the great majority of the Indians are Catholic, the Government renders no less assistance to the Protestant schools, which I consider very right, provided they do not compel the Catholic Indians to attend them. Why, I ask you, have two weights and measures? They assured me at Ottawa that there would be nothing of the sort; and I am quite determined to maintain...
maintain my right, and the right of the Indians.

With regard to Saddle Lake, I regret that the missionary, yielding to the advice of the Agent, asked leave to build from you.

This permission I have in writing from the Right Hon. the Premier. I do not see why one should wish to compel it to be sought from one whose authority is subordinate. There are at least a hundred Catholic Indians who call for a permanent mission at Saddle Lake, and they would be denied it, because the chiefs, who for the most part live at Whitefish Lake, are opposed to it.

I can assure you that had I not been obliged to be away the whole summer, the house would have been built today. The wood is purchased, lying on the banks of the Saskatchewan, exposed to the danger of being burnt, because you did not consider it right to grant the permission which they had the want of tact to apply to you for. I do not wish, Sir, in the least to fail in respect to you, but I maintain that the Indians have the
the right, according to all their treaties, to exercise the religion of their choice, even if they be in the minority.

Since they have this right, it is necessary that they be in a position to exercise it; and they cannot, unless they have a mission at their door. The Government at Ottawa has recognized this right; and it has acknowledged to me the right to give them missions and priests, and every agent of the Government cannot do less than recognize and protect it.

Sir,

With reference to the complaints against Mr. Venne, teacher at Meadow Lake, which by your letter above quoted, were referred to me to be reported on, I have the honour to state as follows:

I reached Meadow Lake reserve at 9.30 a.m. on the 6th of June, and found that Mr. Venne was away at Battleford on private business. He had been away about a week, and was expected back in two or three days.

On examining the register I found that the statement made in Mr. P.L. Morin's letter concerning Mr. Venne's trips to Isle à la Crosse and to Duck Lake is correct. But those trips were made between the 12th and the 31st of March, during which period the school is represented as closed, both in the register and in the quarterly return.

As the return was found to agree with the register I then endeavored to test the correctness of the register.

Mr. P.L. Morin was absent from home as I passed.
passed Green Lake both going and coming. His father, however, is a settler and trader near Meadow Lake reserve, about 2½ miles from the school, and a man of whose veracity all the oldest settlers in those regions speak highly. I asked him if he knew anything definite as to the way this school was conducted. He said after some hesitation that the school was closed since last November. As the school is the teacher's house I asked him if it might not be that a few children attended of whom he did not know. He admitted that one family might have attended.

This is the Mirasty family, and they are the only children whom the register shows as having attended, for the average for the quarter is only 3.36. He said, however, that even if these did attend occasionally it could not be called a school, for they did not attend except a day now and again, and they came and went at all hours.

There was only one male Indian on the reserve. He is a relative (he claims to be a brother) of the above mentioned Mirasty. He also maintained that the school was closed all winter.

The quarterly return shows that "the school was closed from the 14th. of March till the 31st", and although it is supposed to have been open since for some two months, yet the register has
has never been marked since the 12th of March.

From the foregoing facts I formed the opinion that while the school was nominally open it was practically closed, and that the register was not trustworthy as an accurate record of attendance. The circumstances seem to indicate that it has been written up at intervals from memory and somewhat at random.

As for taking holidays in June there could be no better time (at least in the early part of June) since the Indians, old and young, were nearly all away bear-hunting. But March was not a suitable time as there is very little hunting done then.

There are, however, sufficient indications that the school, whether open or closed, is doing no work of any value. Mr. Venne has no influence with the Indians to induce them to send their children to school. Moreover, he has become interested in stock-raising to such an extent that it claims both his time and attention, and that almost entirely.

It cannot be expected, however, that for the meagre salary a teacher can be induced to go to that remote part and devote himself exclusively to teaching.

I would therefore strongly recommend that the Day School be closed and that an effort be made to induce the Indians to send their children to Isle à la Crosse Boarding School.

Report on Inspection of Battleford Agency from October 1st 1911, to March 31st 1912. Date of inspection, March 8th to 26th, 1912.

Although J.U. Paquet has been in charge of the Meadow Lake reserve for a year or more as overseer and teacher, yet this was the first opportunity I had had of inspecting his work. I regret to have to say that I formed a very poor impression as to his reliability and trustworthiness. The information furnished by his diary was very indefinite and unsatisfactory; and in many instances it was impossible to determine whether the references were to his own work or that of the Indians. I was informed by Rev. Father Cochin, whose mission is just outside the reserve, about two and a half miles from the Farmer's dwelling, that the school is a mere sham and exists only in name. The same was said by half breeds living within half a mile from the teacher's house. The school room, such as it is, is under the same roof with the teacher's dwelling, and the statement is made by all the neighbours that it is an unusual thing to see an Indian child around the place at all. On the day of my visit the teacher maintained there was only one pupil on the reserve, and that he sent for him and could not get him to come. There are no evidences of school work to be seen.

Respectfully submitted,
Sgn. W.J. Chisholm
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

As the result of the burning of the Thunderchild Indian Residential School, the Indians of the Meadow Lake Reserve are very anxious to have a day school on their reserve. Reverend Father Allard, the Roman Catholic missionary at that point, has started a small day school with very poor facilities in an old discarded Government building on the reserve. It is a log building and cannot be made suitable for a school. However, he is carrying on as well as he is able to, doing some of the teaching himself, and getting some free assistance from a young lady living in the town of Meadow Lake, about a mile away from the school.

While the establishment of a day school on the Meadow Lake Reserve may not be entirely in agreement with the wishes of some of the heads of the Church, I must say that Reverend Father Allard is certainly very anxious to have one, and, in my opinion, has very good grounds for the stand which he is taking.

The living conditions of the Indians, and the situation of the homes on the Meadow Lake Reserve make a day school much more practical than on most Indian reserves. I have not been informed of the exact number of day schools which have been authorized for Saskatchewan this year. We have practically settled upon Nut Lake, Poorman's, and Chitek Lake each for a combined day school and teacherage, and Thunderchild Reserve for a classroom without a teacherage. In addition to this, it was tentatively decided to build a day school on the White Bear's Reserve to take the place of the present St. Francis R.C. Day School, which is using the Church for a classroom.

If funds are not available for a combined classroom and teacherage at Meadow Lake Reserve in addition to these, I would be in favour of delaying the erection of the classroom at the White Bear's Reserve another year, substituting for this a combined classroom and teacherage at the Meadow Lake Reserve.

Please give this matter consideration and instruct me as to the decision of the Department.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

I was pleased to receive your personal letter concerning the proposed day school on the Meadow Lake Reserve. I have also received your official letter and have written to you in regard to this matter, officially.

I realize the situation only too well with regard to Father Allard and the church authorities. I recently had an opportunity of discussing a similar situation with Father Laviolette, whose views you already know. Upon your recommendation and that of Major Clark, we are prepared to erect a one-room day school with attached teacherage at Meadow Lake. We will have to be very certain that the number of children warrants the expenditure. In Manitoba we have been operating these day schools in churches for a year or two and then, if we found the Indians cooperating, we have been building proper day schools. Dear Mr. Ostrander:

Meadow Lake Indian Day School.

I have for answer your letter of June 21st.

We are paying the foreman carpenter at Valley River $1.50 per hour. We are paying his two sons $1.25 per hour. We have found that the cost of the materials for the schools vary widely. This is due to the fact that in certain provinces, the mills and building supply companies are not keen to tender on ready built cupboards, stairs, etc., as called for in our specifications. However, the total cost of the materials varies between $5,500 and $6,500.

The school at Oak River, Manitoba, cost around $1,300.00 using a foreman carpenter. Mr. Doucet tells me that this is one of the best finished schools of this type that he has seen.

In addition to paying the foreman carpenter and other labourers, we usually arrange for the rent of a bull dozer for the time necessary to do the excavation. We also arrange to rent a cement mixer and a man to operate it, where it is necessary. We even have one small agency in Ontario, where the Agent himself is actually supervising the construction of the building with Indian labour. As you know, the plans and specifications are very detailed and fairly easy to read.

I hope that this is the information that you require. We are only too well aware of the fact that the Saskatchewan labour regulations make your labour costs higher than those in other areas.

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 3rd instant, File 105-3-8 (A.M.), in connection with the tender of Mr. Olof Lidforss for the erection of the combined classroom and teacherage at the Meadow Lake Reserve.

I have been unable to get a second quotation on this building, and I regret that the fact was not stated in my letter referred to by Mr. Mills, Chief Engineer.

As you are aware, Holterman and Sons are building the Butte Lake Day School and the Poorman's Day School. In addition, they have agreed to build two warehouses for us before this winter, consequently the whole of their time for this season will be taken up. Axel Olson gave a quotation last year on a similar building at the Chitek Lake Reserve, or the Carlton Agency, and his tender was not accepted because it was considered too high. When approached again this year, he informed me that he would not lower his quotation below the tender he submitted last year, as he said in the meantime the cost of material has risen considerably. I may say quite definitely that unless Mr. Lidforss' tender for the school at Meadow Lake is accepted as submitted, this school cannot be built this year. I note the fourth paragraph of Mr. Mills' letter, a copy of which was forwarded to me, to the effect that ".....where they do submit a tender, it is based, not on what the project is worth, but what they consider they can obtain. There is no evidence of prices being based on a fair profit above the cost of labour and materials." I may say in this connection that Mr. Lidforss would be quite willing to take on the contract for the Meadow Lake School on a cost plus basis. If that is the wish of the Lands and Development Services Branch I shall approach Mr. Lidforss to accept the work on that basis, but I fear that we will later regret having done so. Mr. Lidforss is not a racketeer in the construction business. He is an honest, conscientious workman who values his services at a certain rate. If he cannot take a contract with a hope that his financing of the contract, plus his own time, at a reasonable rate, will give him the return he requires, he will not take the contract, as his time is very much in demand, and he does not have to look for work.

Mr. Lidforss' home is in Meadow Lake, consequently he prefers contracting jobs in that area, and will quote a lower price on them because of saving the transportation costs. There is a great deal of building going on in all parts of this province, and all good contractors have far more work ahead of them than they can handle this year. People who have building jobs to be done are faced with awarding the contract at the contractor's price, or waiting for some time for contractors to reduce their prices.

I note also the remarks of Mr. Mills with regard to having similar buildings erected for $13,500.00 to $14,000.00. If he will inform me where there is a contractor in Saskatchewan who will erect one of these buildings at anywhere near $14,000.00 I shall immediately interview him. I have driven hundreds of miles endeavouring to find contractors interested in work for us, and Holterman Brothers, and Olof Lidforss, are the only ones who were interested enough to bother examining the plans. I believe Mr. Mills should be again reminded that minimum wage laws in Saskatchewan are considerably different from any other province, therefore it is useless for him to continue reminding me that a certain job can be done for less money in other provinces. I am quite aware of the fact, but, happen to be interested only in Saskatchewan, and problems of building in Saskatchewan.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

J.A. Davis, Esq., Indian Superintendent, MEADOW LAKE, Saskatchewan.

The Department has referred to me an extract from your report on the Meadow Lake Indian Day School for the month of November, in which there is a paragraph devoted to lack of punctuality in the pupils arriving at the school, wherein you state they "kept drifting in from 9.30 to 10.30 A.M."

In the final analysis you are the only one who can deal with this in a practical manner. The extent to which your action will prove effective depends almost entirely upon the extent to which you can impose your will upon the parents of such children (any suitable manner short of actual force).

I am well aware that it is not your duty to visit the Indian homes early in the morning to cook breakfast for their children, but I am also aware that most Superintendents, and many Assistants, have been successful, by continual attention to the problem, to have good day school attendance and punctuality.

Please give this matter immediate attention, advising me of the action you have taken and, in due course thereafter, the results which you have accomplished.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith a letter received from Mr. J.T. Warden, Field Assistant, Regina Office, in connection with a proposed Indian Day School for the Loon Lake Reserve, of the Meadow Lake Agency.

Mr. Warden has just returned from Meadow Lake where he was in charge of the agency following the death of the late Mr. H.S. Packman. I asked him while at the Meadow Lake Agency to enquire into the possibility of renting the building referred to in his report.

There has recently been erected in the Loon Lake Village a good school to accommodate all of the white children of the village, and nothing has been done with the old village school building. Mr. Warden informs me that this building is in good condition with the exception of a need for paint, and that it is large enough to accommodate 35 children. There are only about 20 children of school age on the Loon Lake Reserve, and they all live reasonably close to the Loon Lake Village.

I have hesitated about recommending the erection of an Indian day school for the Loon Lake Reserve, but I am entirely in favour of renting the building referred to for one term, as an experiment. If the Indian parents take sufficient interest in the education of their children that the children will attend school regularly, consideration might be given later to buying the building referred to, and moving it on to the reserve, a distance of about ½ mile or a mile from its present site. I would also warn the parents that if the attendance in the proposed temporary day school is not satisfactory they will not be given a day school, and their children will have to be sent away to a residential school.

The Indians of the Loon Lake Band are practically all Anglicans, and I presume that the Anglican Church would expect the school to be operated under their auspices. It will be noted that Mr. Warden....
Regina, February 7th, 1949.

J.P.B. Ostrander, Esq., Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
REGINA, Saskatchewan.

In accordance with your instructions I looked into the possibility of obtaining a building suitable for school purposes to be used for the children of the Loon Lake Indian Reserve. The small building formerly used by the Village of Loon Lake is available, at a cost of $25.00 per month rent. It is a frame building 24' x 36', on cement foundation, but without a basement. The building is unpainted on the outside, but otherwise in good condition. There is no furniture in the building with the exception of a box stove.

The school is situated within Loon Lake Village Limits and is approximately ¼ of a mile from the Indian reserve boundary. There are about 20 children on the Loon Lake Reserve of school age, whose parents are anxious that a school be made available for them, and there is a possibility of our being able to purchase the building in question at a later date from the School Unit Board. In the event of satisfactory school attendance the building could be moved on to the reserve.

I might add that there is an ex-school teacher available who would be willing to take the position, and she is a married woman.

I would recommend that the matter of opening a school for the benefit of the Indian children on this reserve be given your favourable consideration.

J.T.S. Warden,
Field Assistant, Regina Office.

Re: Your file 278-316-11A (171)

Further to my letter to you of February 9th and your
letter of February 12th:

Re: Paragraph Two: I wish to thank you for the informat-
ion contained in the letters attached.

Re: Paragraph Three: I wish to state that it was the
farthest from my thoughts that Indian children and White children
should not mix, but I had been talking to a couple of the Unit
Board Directors previous to writing you and their re-action to
the children mixing was that they felt that the parents of the
White children in Loon Lake would object. In order to further
clarify the situation with respect to the school I attended the
Unit Board meeting yesterday where this matter was fully discussed.
I drew to the attention of the Board that there was no possibility
of recommending rental of the school building in its present
situation if the White people were going to object to the Indian
children mixing with theirs. It was suggested that possibly
recess periods could be staggered and in that way overcome their
imaginal problem. It was finally decided that the Director,
Mr. Studor, representing that part of the school district would
call a meeting and interview the interested parties and would
report back to the Board his findings regarding the two schools
being in operation so close together.

A letter from the Unit Board dated February 1st, copy of which
was attached with letter of February 9th, sort of confuses the
issue in that they were agreeable to rent the building at $25.00
per month and yet this same board seem to be of the opinion that
the White and Indian children should not mix. I further pointed
out to them that actions such as this did not offer much co-operation
in trying to assist our Indian population of becoming better citizens.
In the meantime, would recommend that no further action be taken
until such times that we have definite assurance that the Indian
children can have the same use of the play grounds as the White
children. When the report is received from Mr. Studor we will
forward same to you for your perusal.

Mention at the Board Meeting was made re: purchase of the
building to be moved onto the Reserve. The Board was not in a
position to set a price. They might be prepared to sell it so that
matter is now left in abeyance.

Regina, February 12th, 1949.

J.A. Davis, Esq., Indian Superintendent, MEADOW LAKE, Saskatchewan.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, File 281-1-(171), regarding use of the old school building in the Village of Loon Lake by Indian children.

Attached is copy of the report of Mr. Warden to me in this connection, and copy of my letter to the Department, recommending that arrangements be made to rent the building. I have not yet had a reply to my letter to the Department, but I shall advise you of the result as soon as I receive a reply.

Regarding the second paragraph of your letter referred to, please advise me why you are of the opinion that "it would be far more satisfactory to have the children moved out on to the reserve where the white and Indian children would not be so closely associated."

I may say, for your information in the future, that it has been the recommendation of the Joint Committee of Parliament, which has been in conference for two years considering revision of the Indian Act and all other matters relating to the service to, and welfare of, Indians, that whenever the opportunity arises Indian children should be encouraged to associate with white children in both education and recreation, and you may consider quite definitely, that this is the policy which we hope to follow in the future. Of course, if the Unit Board controlling the rental of the school building are so short-sighted and narrow minded that they object to our Indian children playing on the same school grounds with the white children, and refuse to rent the building to us unless it is moved on to the reserve, there is little that we can do about it. However, it will be your duty to discuss this phase of the matter with the Unit Board and ascertain their re-action.

You will note that in my letter to the Department I have recommended that if attendance proves satisfactory at the school in its present location, consideration might be given later to buying the building and moving it on to the reserve. I may say that in making that recommendation I did not have in mind the desire which you appear to have, to segregate our Indian children. My only reason in making such recommendation was that if we were to own the building, it would have to be located on an Indian reserve and, by moving it on to the reserve it would probably be somewhat closer to the homes of the Indian children.

Another matter in your letter which I should point out to you for your future information is the suggestion that Miss G. Lenine, who is determined to resign from her appointment as day school teacher at the Big Island Lake Indian Day School might be considered as teacher for the Loon Lake Day School. It is the policy of the Department that the church to which the majority of the Indian children belong will have the right to nominate (for Departmental approval) the teacher to be engaged for an Indian day school. I happen to know that Miss Lenine belongs to the R.C. faith, therefore there is small likelihood that she would be nominated by Bishop Martin, of the Anglican Church, for the position. Attention of Colonel Neary

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 23rd instant, File 637-5 (E), regarding the opening of a day school for Indian children of the Loon Lake Band.

I have not yet received a reply to my letter of the 12th instant addressed to Indian Superintendent J.A. Davis, copy of which was sent to the Department with my letter of the 18th instant on the subject.

In the meantime may I suggest that, notwithstanding the demands made upon the Department in the past by Bishop Martin, of the Church of England, that the proposed day school be operated under the auspices of his church, that the new school be non-denominational. I was misinformed that the majority of the Indians of that band were Anglican. The slight majority of one Anglican over members of the Roman Catholic faith does not, in my opinion, justify the operation of the school under the auspices of the Anglican Church, particularly in view of the fact that there is a still greater majority who have not accepted either faith.

I would recommend that the school be non-denominational, and the vacancy for the teacher for the remainder of the present school term be filled by the ex-school teacher mentioned by Mr. J.T. Warden as living in the Village of Loon Lake, who has the necessary qualifications. I may say in this connection that I have not been informed of her name or the religion to which she belongs. I would suggest that an advertisement be inserted in local newspapers to fill the position permanently for the new school term commencing the 1st of September, 1949.

Attached is a requisition for Janitor supplies for the Loon Lake Indian Day School which is anticipated opening on September 1st, 1949.

We have estimated for the year's supply but having had no experience in this request that you check and inform us if we have ordered too much or too little of any commodity.

We have asked for two long handled scrub brushes. These, although slightly more expensive than the ones without handles do a far better job as more leverage is gained. The handleless brushes are for corners and places the others could not reach properly.

As no teacher has as yet been appointed to that school would suggest that supplies come in care of this Agency at Meadow Lake. Once a teacher is in charge supplies could be sent direct via St. Walburg, (C.N.R.) which is about twenty miles closer than Meadow Lake.

As paper cups are of no use for hot lunches we have shown three dozen iron-stone cups and saucers. Paper cups can be used during summer months.

Ottawa, July 9, 1910.

Right Reverend Sir,

A report recently received on the Poundmakers day school shows that the teacher lately appointed is altogether unfit for the position. There is no teacher's dwelling on this reserve, but an unmarried teacher can secure board and comfortable quarters at the farm house, 1½ miles from the school, and the Department is assured that the farmer will co-operate in every way with the teacher in maintaining the attendance and raising the efficiency of the school.

I have to ask Your Lordship, therefore, to take into consideration the appointment of a teacher with proper qualifications and to one with the necessary certificates a salary of $400.00 per annum will be paid. I shall be glad to hear from Your Lordship in connection with this matter at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary,

Right Rev. Albert Pascal, O.M.I., D.D.,
Bishop of Prince Albert,
Prince Albert, Sask.

Sir,

I have the honour to say, relative to the Poundmaker Day School, that an improved School on this Reserve, if it were well conducted, should prove a great success and a benefit to the Indians; as there are now 21 Children of School age, and a lot of others who are nearly old enough to attend too.

Under date of Aug 6th '10 I wrote you stating that the present building is in a ruinous condition, and not worth repairing. I would also recommend that a married man be employed as Teacher: his wife could prepare the noon meal for the children; and I always consider that the presence of a good woman helps to attract the children to the schools.

On this Reserve the homes of the Parents are somewhat scattered; so that when the School would be ready for complete operation; I think that it would be advisable to have the ones who reside far away from the School brought there by some sort of conveyance.

We opened school on the 13th Oct 1913. There was no provision made for cutting wood for school so I had to arrange for it at my own expense. There was not any wood supplied for cooking a meal a day or heating the house where they eat dinner all winter I provided wood and had it cut until the 23rd Oct. The farmer told me hereafter the wood would be provided for the kitchen stove. The house is not fit for habitation hardly, the Catholic church where we have school is not protected very well single windows and not any to well fitting with stove heat makes the situation a trying one for half clothed children to find in going among the Indians. There are 20 school children on Roundmaker so our seating capacity will be filled as I expect a full attendance when the snow is off the ground. The future looks bright and we are having good attendance we are a happy group among ourselves.
I remain. Respectfully,

your obedient servant,
Mrs. Agnes Turney

P.S. I am not complaining but I believe the Department should have the existing circumstances explained why the Poundmaker School is not more of a success, and the poor Indian children are therefore the losers.

5. School Room

The nave of the mission church is utilized as class-room. The building is quite cold; and the box heater situated in the center is sufficient to heat the room only in moderate weather. Fortunately, there has been only about three weeks of very severe weather thus far this winter.

The church is by no means central for the school population of the reserve, being about half a mile from one extremity and about two and a half from the other.

It is, however, a decided convenience for the teacher to be able to occupy the mission dwelling, where also the children's noon meal is prepared and served.

6. Equipment and School Material.

The desks are quite old, home-made and not being fastened to, the floor are quite unsteady. As no writing is done with pen the need for an absolutely steady desk is not so much felt.

The blackboard consists of painted lumber board leaned against the wall, and is of little advantage.

In connection with the schools of this Agency I wish to draw your attention to certain facts regarding them. We have gone into the matter of costs of the Day Schools and from the results produced have come to the conclusion that it would be advisable, both from the point of economy and from an educational standpoint to close some of these schools and have the children sent to the boarding schools. I am submitting figures dealing with this matter which prove that the costs to the Department per head is greatly on the increase and the results attained are on the decrease. Although my reports in the past have in some cases been favourable yet I do not consider that the progress made is in proportion to the cost.

Moosomin Day School.- At this school the cost per head per annum for 1914-1915, 1915-1916 and from Sept. 1916-Sept. 1917 is as follows, $103.75, 151.40 and 176.72. The average attendance during the same periods was 9.86, 8.9 and 6. From this you will see that while in the period from March 1914-1915 the average cost per head was $103.75 it has now increased to $176.72, while the attendance has dropped from 9.86 to 6. From the June report of this year the number of children of school age in the vicinity of the school is given as 13, and the average attendance for the quarter is 4.2 out of 13 on the register. In looking over the attendance at this school you will find that out of the 13 on the register there were only three who attended more days.
than they were absent during the quarter. From all this it will be seen that the Indian parents on this reserve, with few exceptions, do not care whether the children attend or stay away from school. When the average cost per pupil attending school is taken into consideration the rate is far too high. The cost of educating the children at the Thunderchild Boarding School with the increased allowance during the war is considerably lower than at this school. The child attending the boarding school is making far more progress than the child who is attending the day school. He or she are regular attendants at school where in the day school the knowledge acquired today is lost through being absent for the next two or three days. I would therefore consider it advisable in this case to discontinue this school and enforce the compulsory act and compel the Indians to send their children to the boarding school.

Poundmaker School.- At this school the cost per head for 1914-1915, 1915-1916, and from Sept 1916-Sept 1917 is as follows. $140.00, 141.35 and 175.00. The average attendance for the same periods has been 9.1, 10.3 and 8.5. You will see that the average cost has increased from $140.00 to $175.00 and the average attendance has decreased from 9.1 to 8.5. While the difference is not so noticeable in this school as in the Moosomin, yet the cost is away above what it should be in proportion to the results attained. In looking at the June returns of this school we find that there are seventeen in the vicinity of the school with an enrollment of fifteen and an average attendance of 7.6. At this school we find that there are only five who have attended more days than they were absent. The attendance only figures out at 50% which is far too low. In the case of this school it would be far more economical to close it up and either have the children placed in a boarding school or employ a driver and have them all taught at the Littlepine Day School.

Red Pheasant School.- The average cost per head for this school for 1914-1915, 1915-1916 and from Sept 1916-1917 is $73.80, $88.95 and $115.75. The average attendance for the same period was 25.75, 22.20 and 15.20. The average cost in this school has also increased and the average attendance has decreased. The average cost of $115.75 is however much lower than in the two previous mentioned schools. In the June report the number of children of school age in the vicinity of the school is given as 29 and the number on the register as 22 with an average attendance of 13.10 for the quarter. At this school there were 14 who attended more days than they were absent, during the quarter.

Littlepine School.-The average cost of this school for 1914-1915, 1915-1916 and Sept. 1916-1917 was $126.00, $99.65 and $111.90 and the average attendance was 11, 13 and 11. There has not been the same changes in the average cost and attendance as in the other schools. While at this school the attendance has been fair the advancement made by the children has been poor. We trust that the new teacher who is taking the school over on the 1st of next month will show better results. In the June quarter the number shown on the register is 20 which includes all of school age in the vicinity of the school. The average is given as 8.75 which is below the average of the year but compares favourably with the average of 5.5 for the June quarter of the previous year. At this school there were nine who attended more days than they were absent.

From the foregoing it will be seen that the average cost per head for the different schools varies considerably. While in the case of Moosomin and Poundmaker the average for the three years has reached the sum of $143.62 and $152.12 in that of Red Pheasant and Littlepine the average has been $92.83 and $112.52 and the cost of the schools for twelve months from Sept 1916 to Sept 1917 has been for
Moosomin $176.72, Poundmaker $175.00, Red Pheasant $115.75
and for Littlepine $111.90. In the comparison between the
schools as regards the average costs, I have endeavoured
to be as just as possible. The figures for Red Pheasant
and Littlepine includes an allowance of $100.00 per year
for Field Matrons for preparing the noon meals, which is the
same as is allowed for Moosomin and Poundmaker. Red Pheasant
School also includes in its cost the sum of $500.00 for
taking the children to school, which charge is not made
against any of the other schools. In the case of Red Pheasant
and Littlepine no rent was included as these schools are
held in Department buildings, while in the case of Moosomin and
Poundmaker a charge of $240.00 and $300.00 per annum is in-
cluded for rent.

Were it possible I think it would be far
more beneficial to the children if the day schools were taken
away from the partial control of the churches and placed en-
tirely under Department control with graduated normal school
teachers in charge. If it is not possible to do this I would
recommend as an alternative that the Moosomin and Poundmaker
Schools be closed and the children of Moosomin of Catholic
parentage be sent to the Thunderchild Boarding School and those
of Protestant parentage to the Onion Lake Boarding School or
some other Anglican Boarding School. At the Poundmaker Reserve
I think it would be either possible to send the Catholic
children to the Thunderchild Boarding School or as I mentioned
before employ a driver and have them all attend the Littlepine
Day School. At the present time there are attending the Thunder-
child Boarding School, 5 children from Moosomin, 12 from
Poundmaker and 10 from Red Pheasant. There are also 9 children
from Red Pheasant at Onion Lake Boarding School and 2 at
Elkhorn. I think it would be a good rule to follow that when
the average attendance for the twelve months falls below 10
the Day School should be closed and some other disposition be made of the children. I have always urged the parents to send their children to the Day Schools but have met with poor results on the Moosomin and Poundmaker Reserves.

If this report should meet with your approval I would recommend that action be taken at once as regards the Poundmaker and Moosomin Schools.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter of the Agency, in which the Agent states that it has been decided to close the day-school on Poundmaker Reserve, under the consideration that it will be cheaper to place the children of that Band in the Boarding School. Not being aware that such a decision was to be taken I could not express my opinion, and I beg to express it now:

My opinion, based on my own experience of twenty years, is that the Day-Schools on the reserves make no good at all to the Indians, and it is money expended for nothing in keeping these schools. Speaking only of the schools I know, I dare to say that there is more good done to the children in two weeks in our Boarding School than in an entire year in the Day-Schools.

With such an opinion you will understand that I cannot but be pleased with the decision taken, but kindly let me object to the immediate execution of it under the following considerations:

1) At the request of the Agency I have made arrangement to fill the position left by the last teacher, Mrs Tierney. A new teacher has been procured, and has started teaching, and so not caring to look for another position for the present winter. He has made expenses to come to the Reserve with his wife.
2) It is stated that the children of that Band will not be deprived of a school, being to be placed in the Boarding School, but that decision taking me by surprise, I do not see how I could find accommodation to receive these children before next Spring.

In consideration of the circumstances as explained above I beg to make the suggestion that the execution of the decision should be postponed until the 1st of April next.

Kindly let me hear from you if you agree with the suggestion.

Yours respectfully,

March 18th

Sir,

I beg to bring your attention to the fact that no tenders are being called for the erection of a school on the Reserve of Poundmaker. You must be aware, and it is plainly stated in the annual reports of the Department of Indian Education, that there is no school in the Battleford agency that needs more to be remedied than the school at Poundmaker. I am glad to see that a good school is to be built at Little Pine, but in some time I don't understand why nothing is to be done for Poundmaker. The school at Little Pine is in a far better condition than the one at Poundmaker, and if the Department is not ready to build at once on both Reserves, I should think that it would be best to build first at Poundmaker. I am satisfied that...
at Ottawa you are far from being duly informed of the state of affairs in the Battleford Agency. I never wrote to you about that school because I had the promise of Mr. A. Rowland that he would see to it himself, and I am convinced that he never mentioned it.

So I would beg you, Sir, to take this matter into consideration and to give us satisfaction.

Yours,

E. Lacombe

Very respectfully yours,

E. Lacombe

Ottawa, April 1, 1913.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your communication of the 18th ultimo in reference to the erection of a new school building on the Poundmakers Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that the Department was aware that this building is not in the best condition and some minor repairs were made to it two years ago. The school, however, has not been as successful as might be desired and a number of the children of school age are enrolled at the Thunderchild's Boarding School, which school will likely continue to draw a large part of its attendance from this reserve. In view of this the advisability of making any large expenditure in connection with these buildings is doubtful. If, however, it is the wish of the church authorities to continue the day school on the Poundmakers Reserve and endeavour to improve it and if the assurance is given the Department that in the event of expenditure being incurred more competent teachers will be nominated the matter of erecting a day school building will be given consideration.

In your letter you refer to the erection of a new building on the Little Pines Reserve and I may here state that this action is taken by the Department in view of the closing of the Battleford Industrial School, otherwise the old building would have had to serve for sometime yet.

Rev. E. Lacombe, O.M.I.,
Delmas, Sask.
I shall be pleased to hear from you in regard to this matter.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
The Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 1st inst., I beg to state that it is the wish of the Church authorities to continue the day school on the Pauindawas Reserve and to endeavour to improve it by appointing only qualified teachers.

We expect that the department will see at once that a new school be built on Pauindawas Reserve in same time as our little ones, so as to avoid bad feelings between the two reserves.

Believe me, dear sir,

Yours very truly,

E. Lacombe

Ottawa, April 25, 1913.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, and in reply I beg to say that the Department endeavours, if possible, to find teachers with professional qualifications, that is those who have had pedagogical training either in the model or normal schools in some of the provinces and for teachers with such qualifications the Department allows salaries ranging from $500.00 to $700.00 per annum, where there are children to justify the payment of such an amount.

Owing to the location of many of our reserves and the lack of boarding and lodging accommodation it is sometimes very difficult to secure qualified teachers, but it is often possible to obtain the services of competent persons with advanced scholastic qualifications and imbued with an interest in Indian work, to whom the Department is prepared to allow salaries of from $500.00 to $600.00 per annum, although they have not had professional training.

Your communication of the same date in reference to the erection of a day school building has also been received, but, as no provision has been made in the estimates this year for this purpose, the Department cannot undertake the work this season. A note, however, will be made for next

Dear Sir,

Regarding the repairs to be made at the Poundmaker's school and teacher's residence, let me tell you that these repairs will cost about $150.00. The Department considers that situated as these day schools are on the Reserves with free grazing for the cows that 5 or 6 cents per quart should be sufficient.

Your obedient servant,

J. A. Rowland, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.

Sir,

Reference your letter 117,052-5 July 21st 1915.

Personally I think there would be considerable money saved if the Department were to purchase cows for the teachers, as previously recommended by me.

Yours obediently,

19 sept. 1916.

Mr. A. Rowland,
Indian Agent,
Battleford.

Dear Sir,-

Considering the great inconvenience of having the water hauled from Mr Tierney's place and the expenses that it necessitates, I wish you would impress on the Department that it is necessary to have a well dug in the proximity of the Poundmaker School. Already I have begun the work and we are down about 17 feet deep in a place where we are sure to find good water at a depth of between 30 and 35 feet, according to an expert in the matter. So far I have incurred all the expenses, but my finances don't permit to finish it. If the Department would take upon themselves to finish that well, it would be a saving of much money and would give better satisfaction to the teaching staff of the Poundmaker School.

Hoping that you will take this letter into consideration,

I am, dear sir,

Yours very truly,

"signed"

E. Lacombe O.M.I.
IN INDIAN AGENT'S OFFICE,

Battleford, Sask.,

September 27th 1916

Sir,

I beg to advise you that I have received a letter from Rev. P. Lacombe, a copy of which is here attached, asking for assistance in sinking a well for the use of the Poundmaker School.

I do not think that it is advisable for the department to assume this expense, as the Catholic Church are receiving twenty dollars a month for the rent of these buildings and should provide a well at their own expense.

Yours obediently,

Indian Agent

J. D. McLean Esq.,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, October 10, 1916.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo enclosing a copy of a communication from the Rev. E. Lacombe asking for assistance in sinking a well for the use of the Roundmaker School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will make an allowance of $25.00 towards sinking this well and you will be good enough to inform Father Lacombe accordingly. This is all the Department is prepared to allow for this purpose. When this well is finished no further payments will be made for water for this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. A. Rowland, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

POUNDMAKER DAY SCHOOL.

This school is on Poundmaker Reserve and is about three miles east of the Little Pines School. The buildings used are the Roman Catholic church and mission house which are rented and used as school and teacher's residence, besides answering their regular purpose. The buildings are well lighted and always kept clean and orderly.

Mr. J. M. Seeber is the teacher and Mrs. Seeber serves the noon-day meal to the children.

The attendance here is also very poor and the children all in the junior class. The people here also cannot be induced to take any interest in the school or the education of their children and it requires continual prodding to keep the few that are attending at school.

S. L. Macdonald,
