In regard to the buildings on Pinetree Reserve, it is not possible that there is no preparation for the coming winter, in regard to a suitable house for the teacher, as the present building is quite impossible and at the present time the teacher has full possession. It is an old frame house with foundation crumbled away, door and windows decayed and roof leaks badly. The building was struck with lightning at one time leaving a hole over the only space where a bed can be placed.
the summer rains flow freely in, also
the winter snow drifts through.
The kitchen floor is badly worn and,
in splinters. The door sills are worn
away and one can slip their finger
between the door and casing. I am not
here to find fault merely stating facts.
Knowing the generosity of the department,
I hope you will give the matter some
consideration. I asked Mr. Echombe about this
matter and he referred me to you.

About the church building were
we have school. I would suggest a
certain betterment. I see why the body
of the church is the large shape
makes a draft that is very unpleasant
and if there are any improvements
to be made... the agent or the inspectors
can be referred too as they have been
in cold winter days and think the
place unusually cold about year end
a foot ball for recess time would
be very glad.
I hope I have not imposed on your valuable time, but for humanity's sake, there certainly should be something done for the school children and the school buildings at Ponemah.

I am your obedient servant,

Ottawa, January 31, 1911.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant in reference to the establishment of an improved day school on the Foundmaker's reserve.

In reply I beg to say that in view of the large expenditure the Department is already under obligation to meet during the coming season it is not prepared to take action in so far as providing new buildings is concerned till next year.

I am sending you herewith a lithographed print of the plan of the reserve and I have to ask you to be good enough to locate approximately thereon the location of the present building and the homes of the Indians, showing in each case the number of children of school age in each head and also the roads or trails leading to the school.

I have also to ask you to report fully upon the work being conducted by Miss Favel.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. P. G. Day, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.
IN INDIAN AGENT'S OFFICE,

BATTLEFOOD.

OCTOBER 9TH 19II.

Reference your Letter No II7052 / I, January 31st 19II.
Also my Letter No IO, June 16th 19II.

Sir,-

I have the honour to say that the Poundmaker Day School has not yet commenced business for this Quarter; and I have been unable to secure a Teacher for $300.00 per Annum. I would respectfully suggest that the Salary should be raised to $500.00 per Annum, for which sum I have no doubt a competent Teacher could be secured; and as there are a large number of Children on this Reserve, they would certainly benefit by having a good Teacher; and especially would this be the case if the School were conducted on the improved day School plan. When the Department establishes the proposed new improved Day Schools on the Poundmaker and Little Pine Reserves, I consider that the most practical and economical manner would be to build one School House mid-way between these two Reserves, with two separate Class-rooms, and one room for the noon meal; this plan I think, would prove to be very convenient and facilitate the work of operating these two Schools.

I am returning herewith the lithographed Plan of Poundmaker Reserve, shewing the location of the Houses and the number of children in each.

Yours obediently

Indian Agent

J. D. McLEAN ESQ'RE.

I have the honor to represent to the Department the difficulties we are beginning to experience in the matter of erecting school houses on such of our Indian Reserves as are not able to supply building logs for that purpose. A case in point is Piapot. We are anxious to establish a school on that Reserve, but the Agent informs me, that the Indians have used up all the building timber obtainable in the erection of houses for them selves.

May it please Your Honor,

Two letters about the erection of the School House on the Piapot Reserve and the Industrial School have been received conveying the intelligence that the recommendation of Your Honor for a grant of £450 to assist erecting a school on the above named Reserve had been approved and the other dealing specially with the Industrial school.

His Honor

MEMORANDUM:

RE EDUCATIONAL SITUATION
FILE HILLS RESERVE
SASKATCHEWAN.

To the Honourable FRANK OLIVER
MINISTER OF THE INTERIOR
SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
OTTAWA, ONT.

HONOURABLE and DEAR SIR,

Allow me to call your benevolent attention to a most important fact that will come in conflict with both the law concerning Indian Education and our principles in education.

The Department of Indian Affairs is establishing a day school at the Indian Colony on the File Hills Reserve, designed to give "secular" education only to the children of the Indians of the Colony, the appointment of the teacher and the management of the school to be in the hands of the Department.

In order, it is said, to make this school a success, the recruiting of pupils in the Colony for Indian boarding and Industrial schools has been prohibited by the Department.

It is alleged in justification of the Department's action that, while the residential schools, boarding and industrial, at one time, filled a need, conditions are so changed that the second generation of Indians are in a position, "as is the case with white people", to train at home their girls in domestic work and their boys in agriculture. That training is, therefore, is to be left to the Indians and "the Department will provide for the secular education by establishing a day school under the charge of an efficient, qualified teacher".

And to compel the success of this new system, regardless of
what the wishes of the Indian parents may be, their children are debarred entrance to boarding and industrial schools (maintained at great public expense for the education of Indians) even before the day school is ready to commence operations.

The new policy enunciated by the Department of Indian Affairs is that the boarding and industrial schools must give way to day schools, and that those day schools are to be secular.

It is a doctrinaire policy; and, apart altogether from the religious and constitutional phases of the subject, one that should be very thoroughly canvassed by men of practical experience in Indian educational work and of large and long acquaintance with Indian conditions before being adopted as the Indian educational policy of the Government of Canada.

Residential schools have been and are being established for the training of the sons of our farmers in farming, cattle raising and dairying and of the girls in farm-house economy, which experience has slowly convinced us cannot adequately be imparted in the homes of a race civilized for centuries.

But the Department of Indian Affairs concludes that it has brought certain of the aborigines to such a degree of civilisation and culture that what cannot be done in the homes of white farmers can be done in the homes of red-men, while it supplies in public schools secular education for the Indian children.

Now, I am in hope that this departure from practice of the department of Indian Affairs is not all a new policy entered upon without public discussion and without the knowledge or consent of Parliament which is charged with the trusteeship of the Indian ward of the nation and which provides the funds for the education of the Indian children of Canada.

Coming to the religious question I beg leave to say that, in Canada, is has never before been seriously questioned that moral training should be a part of the curriculum of the Indian schools. The different religious denominations working among Indians conduct denominational religious schools. No authoritative pronouncement has ever been made by such denomination against such system and in favor of the substitution of secular system.
And you know yourself, Honourable and Dear Sir, that when you called at Ottawa a meeting of the representatives of the different bodies in charge of Indian education it was clearly declared and well understood that education would be denominational, so that we have heard with great surprise of the contemplated establishment of an Indian secular day school at Pile Hills.

Moreover, the attitude of Catholics upon the general question of education is so well understood that it cannot for a moment be believed that they would acquiesce in such a system of Indian education as that now fixed upon by the Department of Indian Affairs. When they have contended unceasingly and universally for religious schools for whites, and have borne great burdens in certain portions of Canada to maintain them, Catholics could not be expected to acquiesce in the creation of a secular system of education for Indians. For if they contend for religious schools for the children of peoples civilized for ages they must, with ten-fold force, insist upon the maintenance intact of the long established, well tried and well accounted for system of religious schools for Indians, advanced a little today but yesterday savages.

I am so confident in your spirit of justice and fair play that I will take the liberty of adding that, fortunately, the law is on our side.

Parliament, among its early decrees, enacted that Indian education should be denominational. The law is still on the Statute Book. Sub-sections 2 and 3 of Section 97 of Chapter 81 of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1906, provides as follows:

"2. If the majority of the band belongs to any denomination the teacher of the school established on the reserve shall belong to the same denomination.

"3. The protestant or Catholic minority of any band may, with the approval and under regulations made by the Governor in council, have a separate school established on the reserve.

Assuredly, Honourable and Dear Sir, the Department of Indian Affairs cannot, in the very face of the law, intend to inaugurate a system of schools for Indians in any way at variati-
ce with the policy of those enactments by establishing secular day schools for Indians and even going as far as prohibiting the admission of Indian children of a certain territory into residential schools existing under State Regulations maintained by Parliament.

What we humbly ask, just now, in the name of the constitutional rights of Indians is that the Department of Indian Affairs suspends its course of establishing that secular day school at File Hills and that the prohibition of admission of Indian children of this district to the Industrial school at Qu'Appelle be withdrawn.

Hoping that the course entered upon at File Hills Reserve, by the Department of Indian Affairs will be reconsidered and that the clouds threatening not only Qu'Appelle Industrial school but all the Indian Industrial Schools shall be dispelled, I remain,

Honourable and Demz Sir,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

PRIZES FOR THE BEST LOCAL OPTION ESSAYS

The local option committee of Ingersoll has decided to offer prizes to the pupils of the High, Public and Separate schools who submit essays on the advantages of local option and the evils of the present system. The prizes consist of prizes, one for the High School, one for the public school and one for the separate school consisting of three prizes, the first prize being $5, the second of $4 and the third of $3. The essay must be written by the pupils of the High School and the separate school will be judged separately. The writer of each essay must use a pen name with which to sign the essay and then place it in an envelope marked "local option" and mail it in a sealed envelope to the president of the committee. Mr. W. G. Gibson will be appointed to judge the essays and will not know the real names of the writers. The names of the winners and the committee will distribute the prizes. It is promised that there will be a meeting at which the prize essays will be read.

In reply, I delayed my answer to this letter because I first wanted to see Mr. Jones, the Indian Agent at File Hills, and Mr. Rhodes, the Principal of the File Hills School. After talking this matter over with the Principal and the Agent I have learned that two Indians on the File Hills Colony, Fred Dieter and David Bird, are behind the movement to build a Day School, and they are being upheld by the United Church Missionary there, Miss Ruth Lanigan. Apparently it was decided that this would be handled on the quiet so that the Agent and the Principal of the School would not know anything about it.

At the present time there are 16 children from the File Hills Colony attending the File Hills School. Mr. Rhodes informs me that only one will be discharged this term and several young children are entering the School in the Fall. Therefore in all probability when the School opens the File Hills Colony will have supplied one fifth of the pupils in attendance.

I quite realize that our Branch have no intention of building a Day School at the Colony at the present time but I want to advise you that when the time comes, we will have to be prepared to build a Day School in the Qu'Appelle Agency and the Crooked Lake Agency because the Indians in these two Agencies have been advocating Day Schools. Referring to your communication of the 8th instant with regard to release of security furnished by Mr. N. Ferguson in connection with the contract awarded him for the erection of a teacher's residence at File Hills Colony, I beg to say that it is not possible for the executive officers of the Government to release securities in the manner suggested. Under an Order in Council passed on the 16th June, 1888, confirming a report made by the Deputy Minister of Finance, it is provided that "hereafter all proceeds of cheques and all deposits on account of contractors' securities shall be deposited in the Government Savings Bank until the contract is completed, when the amount due with such interest as may have accrued under the rules governing a deposit in such Bank will be returned to the depositor."

I think under the circumstances named in your letter that it would be quite reasonable to get an Order in Council authorizing the return of the security. This course has been frequently

Ottawa, 13th November, 1911.

Sir:-

With reference to letter to you of the 8th November, regarding the security deposit made by Mr. Ferguson, in connection with the contract awarded him for the erection of the Teacher's residence at File Hills Colony, I beg to say that it is not possible for the Executive officers of the Government to release the security in question, owing to the fact that the contract is not complete. As intimated in letter to you of the 8th November, the Department of Finance was written to in the matter and a request made for the deposit. A reply has been received stating that an Order in Council was passed in June 1888, which prohibits such a course of action.

It is expected that the Department will have funds towards the close of the present month wherewith to pay outstanding accounts, and settlement will be made as promptly as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

With reference to your letter #42114-9-3 (E) of the 10th inst., I wish to report as follows.

We have been able to locate a plentiful supply of good water on the proposed site and we will be able to complete the work on this well at an approximate cost of $100.00; this work will be commenced immediately.

With reference to the water supply for the Day-School on the old Residential school site, I wish to report as follows.

The present supply is obtained from a well which is over 200 ft deep and cannot be operated without an engine etc.; this method is very unsatisfactory and the average Day School Teacher would not be able to keep it in operation; therefore I would recommend that a dug-out, which was commenced last year, be completed and a well be dug alongside the dug-out and connected by a seepage drain; a small pump could then be installed; the total cost of this work would be approximately $400.00; therefore the total cost of providing water for both schools would no be very much more than the amount already granted.

Please wire authority if granted, as the drag-line outfit is now in the vicinity of the school.

Frank Booth,
Superintendent

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

File Hills Colony Indian Day School, Peepeekisis Reserve,
File Hills-du'Appelle Superintendency, Saskatchewan.

Included in our Main 1949-50 Estimates is the sum of $32,000.00 for the erection of a two-room Indian Day School and attached teachers' residence on the above reserve. This school, along with the present classroom block, will replace the File Hills Residential School to be closed effective June 30, 1949.

The United Church has agreed to the closing of the residential school on the understanding that we erect this two-room school with attached teachers' residence at the File Hills Colony. Would you please, therefore, approve the necessary requisition to the Departmental Purchasing Agent for the advertising of tenders as indicated.

Director.

TENDERS addressed to the Director, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Canada, and endorsed "Tenders for File Hills Colony School(s)", will be received until noon on July 15th, 1949, for the construction by contract of:

1. File Hills Colony Two-room Indian Day School with attached teachers' residence, Peepeekisis Indian Reserve, File Hills-Qu'Appelle Superintendency, Saskatchewan.

Contractors shall tender in complete accordance with the relevant drawings, specifications, and tendering documents supplied by the Department of Mines and Resources. Contractors may tender on one or more of these projects.

The drawings, specifications and other documents will be exhibited at the following points from June 23rd, 1949, until July 15th, 1949, inclusive:

1. Regional Supervisor's Office, Regina, Saskatchewan.
2. Indian Superintendent's Office, Fort Qu'Appelle, Saskatchewan.

General instructions to Tenderers. Drawings and Specifications are obtainable at the above offices upon deposit of Five Dollars ($5.00) in the form of a certified cheque made payable to the Receiver General of Canada. This deposit will be refunded upon return of the drawings and specifications in good condition to either:

1. Regional Supervisor's Office, Regina, Saskatchewan.
2. Indian Superintendent's Office, Fort Qu'Appelle, Saskatchewan.

within one month from the date on which tenders closed.

To receive consideration, tenders must be submitted on the tender forms provided and must be accompanied by a certified cheque on a chartered Bank in Canada, payable to the order of The Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources, equal to ten per cent (10%) of the amount of the tender, or Bearer Bonds of the Dominion of Canada or of the Canadian National Railway Company and its constituent companies, unconditionally guaranteed as to principal and interest by the Dominion of Canada, or of the afore-mentioned bonds and a certified cheque if required to make up an odd amount.

The Department reserves the right to reject any or all tenders, and the lowest tender will not necessarily be accepted.

H. L. Keenleyside,
Department of Mines and Resources,

In order to clarify the day school situation on the Peepeekisis Reserve, and in order to retain the names which have come to acquire significance with the Indians, it has been suggested that we refer to the two day schools as follows:

(1) File Hills Day School - the school to be operated in the classroom block of the present residential school.

(2) File Hills Colony Day School - the new building to be erected at the Colony and for which tenders are now being advertised.

Before finalizing these proposals, we would appreciate your comments in view of your knowledge of local conditions.

In answer to the points raised in your letter of June 17 you may take the following action:

(a) The paint, cedar fence posts and pipe wire fencing can be stored at the Agency and used for day school purposes.

(b) The Dalco lighting plant - This matter will be referred to the Agencies Division when we will write you further.

(c) The sewing machines - These can be used in the day schools, as suggested.

- It
It will also be necessary to refer the matter of the typewriter to the Agencies Division.

It is presumed that you have decided to have the present Principal's residence used for the teacherage at the Pine Hills Day School. It will probably be necessary to have a survey made of the property which will be required for day school purposes. Located on this property should of course be the school and teacherage.

In accordance with our practice elsewhere, it is presumed Mr. Ostrander and yourself will recommend that the remaining buildings and property be declared surplus to our requirements and sold through our Lands and Development Services Branch. Concerning the property you have of course two alternatives:

(a) To add it to the present Indian reserve,

(b) To arrange for its sale through the Lands and Development Services Branch.

I would suggest you arrange locally with the United Church officials to continue in possession of the building until about August 15. They have been given permission to ship the furniture to other residential schools. This does not include the furniture in the principal's residence, which will of course be required for our day school teachers. After they vacate the building, it will be necessary to employ a watchman as otherwise there will be a serious outbreak of vandalism. Previous experience has convinced the Department of the necessity of acting quickly in these matters.

Re: Two Room Day School, Peepeekisis Reserve,

In staking out this work to commence excavating, we found within two hundred feet of the building a practically inexhaustible water spring, which would be ideal for a water supply to allow the installation of a Flushing Toilet System with pressure tanks and pumps and Concrete Cultivating Chamber and Sewage Well, with very little in the way of structural changes to the building itself.

The catch basin at back and outside toilets would be eliminated.

Our suggestion is to put in two girls toilets (Flushing) in the North West Corner of Building, which is the N.W. Corner of coat room. Provincial regulation would then compel us to put in a running water wash basin with two taps to allow for hot and cold water. The North East corner of Boys Cloak Room would be similarly made into a wash room with two flushing toilets, urinal and wash basin. The cubby corner upstairs marked "Chem.Clos." would be enlarged to allow a built-in bath, toilet and wash basin. The Kitchen sink would of course be connected to hot and cold running water. All these fixtures would be properly connected under Provincial regulations to drain to cultivating chamber at Septic Tank where catch basin is shown on existing plan. The Sewage well is sufficiently large that it would not require emptying more than once in a month or two, but a little tiny portable gasoline pump is always provided by us in such cases to set on top of this well and as the water from sewage well is then pure and odorless it can be used to water flowers or vegetable garden or lawns or merely discharged at a distance on the ground. The entire additional cost is $3,400.00 including necessary pressure pump and tank, Septic Tank system complete and all installations in perfect working order.

We enclose a tracing showing suggested structural changes, which are of course also included. We also enclose a blueprint of the septic tank system in common use at buildings under the supervision of Public Works Dept., Ottawa, which Septic Tank Systems are giving perfect satisfaction at every public building where we have installed them. A wired reply would be appreciated.

Sincerely,

Memorandum

Re: File Hills Colony Indian Day School, (Peepeekisis Reserve)

With reference to Major MacKay's memorandum of September 15th which bears your marginal comment of the 19th instant, together with the Contractor's letter and sketches in connection with the above, we submit the following for your information and transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

The Contractor proposes to install a total of eleven (11) plumbing fixtures, drain and water piping and septic tank to serve same with all the necessary auxiliary items for the above. The price of $3,400.00 includes minor structural changes to the building.

It is pointed out that this type of school was designed for areas where outside toilets would be used. If the Contractor's suggestion to install inside toilets is followed, it would mean the pupils of the opposite sexes would have to pass through each of the classrooms in order to gain access to their respective toilets.

It is also pointed out that we have a similar school designed in which a layout for inside lavatory facilities is included.

Since this particular school is already under construction, and if the Indian Affairs Branch wish to adapt the building so that inside toilets may be incorporated, it is our opinion that the Contractor's price of $3,400.00 is fair and just.

We are returning herewith the Contractor's sketches and correspondence.

Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

Encs.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,

I have asked Miss McCaig to write to you if she is interested in opening the File Hills Colony School with her friend. Miss McCaig is a Presbyterian and I believe her friend is United Church.

Proposed Barn, File Hills Colony School

With reference to the above mentioned barn for the Colony Bay School I wish to report as follows.

It will now be necessary to consider the possibility of erecting a barn for the purpose of sheltering the horses, which the pupils use for travelling to and from school; there is no doubt that we should provide such shelter as the winters here are very often severe and we cannot let any horses stand outside as that is one of our main issues with the Indians, that all stock should be protected from the winter weather.

I would recommend that a barn be built for 10 horses on a site adjoining the new school and that it be built on skids so as to enable us to move it at least once a year so that we can clean the place up more easily. It is the most difficult job to have the children keep the barn clean; in fact, I have never seen any Day School barn that at some time I had to hire an Indian to clean out. A barn being movable would facilitate this; I have discussed this matter with Regional Supervisor Ostrander and he is in accord with this type of barn.

I am enclosing a requisition for this proposed barn also quotation from the Harvey Lunam Construction Co. on this building; I would strongly recommend that a barn be built this fall if at all possible; this company is prepared to commence work at once if their offer is accepted.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: File Hills Colony Indian Day School

The above building is now being built by the Harvey Lunam Construction Company, as approved by P.C. 4163 dated August 24th, 1949.

We have recently received recommendations from Regional Supervisor Ostrander that the following additional work be done:

(a) Install electric wiring in the building.
(b) Erect a barn for the pupils' horses.

With regard to the wiring, it is hoped that the hydro will reach the vicinity of the school in the near future, and our officials recommend that the building be wired at the present time in order that it will be ready when electricity is available. The cost of wiring the building while it is under construction will be much less than if we wire it at a later date. The contractors, Harvey Lunam Construction Company, quote a price of $859.25 for supplying materials and installing them in the school.

With regard to the barn, Mr. Ostrander points out that several of the children live a considerable distance from the school, and as a consequence, ride to school on horses owned by their parents. During the winter months it is necessary to have some accommodation for stabling these horses while the children are in school.
The Harvey Lunam Construction Company offer to erect a barn which Regional Supervisor Ostrander states would be satisfactory for an amount of $2,288.00. This includes both the material required and the erection of the barn.

I would appreciate it if the Minister would approve acceptance of the above two tenders.

Director.

Enclosed are two copies of a letter from the Harvey Lunam Construction Company regarding the proposed barn for the File Hills Colony Day School, at a cost of $2,288.00, for your consideration.

You will note that Mr. Lunam has in mind the need for building a barn which can be easily moved to another site which, I believe, agrees with our discussion a few days ago in this office. It has occurred to me that as this barn is suggested for the benefit of the owners of horses which will be used to transport Indian children to and from the school, perhaps the band would be willing to pay the cost of it from their band funds.

I suggest this because of the fact that it would be a good thing to have the barn built while Harvey Lunam's outfit is building the school, and I am sure that no funds have been provided in appropriation for the purpose.

If you think that the barn is badly needed, and you approve of the suggested method of construction, I would be glad if you would discuss it with the band to ascertain their views on the matter of the construction of it being a charge against their funds. MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: File Hills Colony Indian Day School

The above building is now being built by the Harvey Lunam Construction Company, as approved by P.C. 4163 dated August 24th, 1949.

We have recently received recommendations from Regional Supervisor Ostrander that the following additional work be done:

(a) Install electric wiring in the building.
(b) Erect a barn for the pupils' horses.

With regard to the wiring, it is hoped that the hydro will reach the vicinity of the school in the near future, and our officials recommend that the building be wired at the present time in order that it will be ready when electricity is available. The cost of wiring the building while it is under construction will be much less than if we wire it at a later date. The contractors, Harvey Lunam Construction Company, quote a price of $859.25 for supplying materials and installing them in the school.

With regard to the barn, Mr. Ostrander points out that several of the children live a considerable distance from the school, and as a consequence, ride to school on horses owned by their parents. During the winter months it is necessary to have some accommodation for stabling these horses while the children are in school.
The Harvey Lunam Construction Company offer to erect a barn which Regional Supervisor Ostrander states would be satisfactory for an amount of $2,288.00. This includes both the material required and the erection of the barn.

I would appreciate it if the Minister would approve acceptance of the above two tenders.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am in receipt of Department letter of the 30th ultimo, File 641-5 (El), regarding the installation of a lighting plant at the File Hills Colony Indian Day School.

I have instructed Indian Superintendent E.S. Jones, of the Carlton Agency, to have the engine and generator brought in to Prince Albert from Lac la Ronge, and placed in the Department warehouse at Prince Albert, to be examined by Mr. Tegert, electrical technician, who is presently employed in Prince Albert wiring the Post Office Building for the North west Electric Company, under contract with the Harvey Lunam Construction Company.

Mr. Jones will forward me Mr. Tegert's report as to the condition of the engine and generator, and recommendation as to the set of batteries which would best serve. On receipt of the same, if I find that both the engine and generator are in good condition I shall submit requisitions for the cost of the batteries, cost of shipping, and installation.

The matter is rather urgent as the Harvey Lunam Construction Company are nearly finished with their contract of erecting this school, and were about to install a pump with a gasoline engine for pumping the water. If the electric power plant is to be supplied an electric pump would be substituted for the gasoline engine driven pump, and would be much more satisfactory. In the meantime, I have asked the Harvey Lunam Construction Company to delay the installation of the pump until I obtain authority for the installation of the electric plant.

If I could be given authority at this time to purchase the batteries recommended by Mr. Tegert, of the North west Electric Company, providing he finds the engine and generator in good shape, the installation could be expedited considerably. Kindly instruct me in this connection.

J.P.B. Ostrander,

Re Fairbanks-Morse 10 H.P. motor, one generator, and panel, formerly installed at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School, I inspected this motor and found it in a badly worn condition, and in need of extensive repair. The valve guide and valve stem show excessive wear. The valve, valve guides, and valve springs need replacing. The piston is badly scored and I would advise replacement. The crank shaft needs re-grinding and the connecting rods need to be re-metalled. The water pump needs reconditioning and various gaskets will be needed to complete the repair.

From the condition of this engine I would also suggest that the fuel pumps be inspected and repaired before this engine is put into operation. The generator and panel also require overhauling.

D.N. Morrison,
Supervisor of Construction.

A Monsieur A. F. Forget, Commissaire du Département Indien,
Regina.

Honorable Monsieur,

J'ai l'honneur d'appeler votre bienveillante attention sur les considérations suivantes.

Dans la partie Nord-Ouest de mon Vicariat que je viens de visiter, se trouve une très ancienne école, dans la Mission dite de l'Ile à la Crosse. Cette école fondée par le vénéré défunt Monseigneur Taché, et depuis lors dirigée par les Soeurs Grises de Montréal, a beaucoup contribué à l'amélioration des nombreux Indiens qui visitent cette Mission. Cependant le manque de ressources financières a été jusqu'ici le plus grand obstacle à son développement. De là

1. Considérant que le Gouvernement ne refuse pas de venir en aide à tous ceux qui se dévouent au développement intellectuel et moral des enfants Indiens des Territoires du Nord-Ouest;

2. Considérant qu'une Ecole Pensionnat serait d'une très grande utilité pour les nombreuses tribus qui dépendent de la Mission de l'Ile à la Crosse;

3. Considérant aussi les demandes réitérées d'admission à l'école déjà existante sans qu'on puisse accéder aux instances de ceux qui les font;

I have been obliged to take the liberty of writing to you at this juncture. I have been very surprised to receive such a message to go to Isle la Croix at such an advanced season of the year with only one or two companions. We are not probably aware that during three or four days of the journey it is impossible to find any place of rest for the horses, and the risk of losing the goods is so great that the horses can hardly find anything to eat, therefore the double trip was sent only for the provisions for the house to stand by in case of a month's journey. The other double trip was to bring our tents, bedding, tools, and necessary provisions. The single trip was for myself and man.

In such a long journey it would have been very imprudent to take less horses and dogs than I did without incurring the danger of being a long time on the prairie.

As there are no bridges across many large rivers, one of my men
got nearly drowned with the horse
and lost the rig very badly.
Being an old traveler in the North
West particularly in that wild part
of the country, I foresaw the difficulties
that were to be met with especially
when the rivers begin to freeze and
snow on the ground. If I had only
one rig as you imagined, my son
and wife would have been drowned
and I would have been left alone
in the wilderness not less than 250
miles from a living soul.
Permit me also to tell you that my
two other men and myself had great
difficulty to draw the team and the
horses half drowned from the middle
of the river.
As you may understand though our
rigs were not very much loaded,
on several occasions in crossing

trees and one wheel and once where
we were very lucky to have only

We saw several dead horses along

if I had had only one or two horses,

You understand that a man of my age and position would not for any prospect do what I had done if it had not been to please the Government.

Sir,

In reference to your letter No. 17561 dated Ottawa June 18th 1901 I have the honor to forward you the vouchers signed as you requested also a rough diary of my trip to Isle a la Croix last autumn.

A few days after receiving the order from the Department to issue Isle a la Croix Boarding School I started from Duck Lake North three men two double buggies and one single. It may appear strange to you to hear that I brought such an equipment with me but I knew that many travellers left some of their best horses drowned in the mud or on the same road that I had to pass and were obliged to go on foot through the bushes over a hundred miles in order to reach their homes. Not wishing therefore to meet with the same adventure I took what was absolutely necessary for the journey and nothing else.

I found it was very wise to act as
I did, for we nearly lost one of our men horse and rig in crossing a large river. The roads too were so bad that we were obliged to go very slowly and carefully, and several times were delayed by accidents to the rig such as broken wheels, whistles, etc., etc. In order also to avoid marshy places we were often compelled to pass through river roads which made our journey longer.

Having started from Dutch Lake the 16th October, we camped at Carleton, went on to Grassley Lake, Snake Plain, Sandy Lake, Fish River, Devil's Lake, Big River, White Fish Lake, and from there we camped four times in several places. On starting, we struck Clear Lake Water, and proceeded to Green Lake South End, where we took a boat to go to the North End. We had to rest for a day at Green Lake to renew our provisions and wash our clothes. After resting we continued our way to Beaver River, where we found such solid ice on all the back that we were compelled to return. Our wound was now covered with frost and snow, and the old Indians strongly advised me not to go on farther unless I wished to be back.
at Christmas time. We therefore thought it more prudent to return by the same way, and arrived at Duck Lake on the 17th November. Really in good time as the rivers were frozen hard a few days after. My journey lasted thirty-three days, and I candidly acknowledge that no money would oblige me to undertake such a trip at so advanced a season of the year. Hoping that this little detail will be satisfactory, I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Excellence,

Vous voulez bien m'excuser si j'ignore de la maladie qui vous est venue pour le temps que vous avez adressé. Mes sentiments vous honorent plus que les expressions dont je devrais faire état de votre santé. La santé, c'est une chose que nous avons à cœur de garder à ma première lettre, m'encourage à recevoir une seconde fois à l'intention que vous soyez prêt à nos œuvres d'école et de charité.

Les raisons que nous avons causées l'inondation du lac de la Croix ne nous permettent pas de différer davantage la construction d'une nouvelle école orphelinat, sur un terrain plus propice et avec des dimensions plus adaptées au développement de cette œuvre si utile à nos Métis et à nos Indiens du vaste district de l'île de la Croix. Les souffrances auxquelles ont été soumises nos pauvres jeunes filles de Montréal, et que nous ne pouvions éviter faute de ressources ont amené leur rappel, pour cet été, par leur Mère Suprême. Ce sera l'objet d'une douleur immense pour notre chère population, et surtout pour nos chers enfants. Mais Monseigneur Barcel, dans son voyage de France, a trouvé à Lyon des fonds d'un autre institut, qui consentent à venir remplacer de suite les regrettes partout et continuer leur œuvre bénéfique. Nous ne pouvons, Excellence, vous le sentir bien, les espérer plus
longtemps aux funestes inconvénients d'un établissement isolé par la caverne, et, de surcroît nous imposant de nouvelles privations, nous allons nous mettre à l'œuvre. Le chiffre des dépenses dépasse des 7/10 des ressources que nous prévoyons depuis deux ans le département de l'Inde, et qui sont loin de répondre au nombre des enfants indiens de la localité. Nous n'avons que 20 enfants boursiers du gouvernement, et nos Indiens Catholiques (ils le sont tous) dépassent le chiffre de 900, ce qui, avec les Métis donne une population d'environ 1200. D'un autre côté, le pays étant tout sauf nouveau, nous n'avons pas la ressource de la culture sur une bonne échelle. Je supplie donc votre excellente de vouloir bien nous prendre sous la généreuse protection auprès du département de l'Inde, et de nous octroyer soit une augmentation du nombre des boursiers, soit une allocation spéciale qui nous aide à faire face aux dépenses du nouvel établissement.

Cette faveur sera, dans la noble et distinguée carrière de votre Excellence, une bonne et belle action ajoutée à bien d'autres, et que les pauvres Missionnaires de l'Extreme Nord, humbles mais dévoués ouvriers de la plus vraie des civilisations, n'oublieront jamais.

Your Excellency,

You will be kind enough to excuse me if I am ignorant of the formalities used in letters that are addressed to you. My sentiments do you more honour than the forms of expression that may perhaps use. The kindness, moreover, with which you desired to reply to my first letter encourages me to appeal a second time to the interest that you take in our school work and works generally.

The rains that caused the flooding of Lake La Croix will not allow us to put off any longer the building of a new schoolhouse or orphanage on a more suitable piece of land and of a size more adapted to the development of this work so dear to our half-breeds.
and to our Indians of the vast district of St. Lawrence. The sufferings that our poor Grey Nuns of Montreal have been subject to, which we cannot prevent for lack of resources, have been recalled for this summer by the head of their order. This will be the cause of great grief among our dear people, especially for our dear children.

But Bishop Pascal, in his trip to France, found at Lyons nuns of another order, who agree to come at once and take the place of the regretted sisters who are leaving, and to continue their blessed work.

We cannot, as Your Excellency will well understand, longer expose them to the very serious inconveniences of an establishment out of order by water; and although we have to suffer from privations, we are going to start at the work. The expense will exceed $100 of the grant made us for two years by the Educational Council and which is far from sufficient for the number of Indians.
children of the locality. We have only 20 children provided for by the Gov't, and our Indians R.C. Indians (they are all R.C.) exceed the figure 900, which, with the half-breeds, makes a population of about 1200.

On the other hand, the country being all sandy, we haven't the resource of cultivating on a large scale. I therefore beg Your Excellency to be kind enough to take us under your generous protection in respect to the Educational Council, and to obtain for us either an increase in the number of grant-earners or a special grant that will enable us to meet the expenses of the new establishment. This favour will be in the noble and laudable career of Your Excellency a good and fine deed added to many others, and one that the poor missionaries of the extreme North, humble but devoted workers for the truest civilization, will never forget.
Please accept, Your Excellency,
my sincere homage and respect
in O.T. and M.V.

Priest, O.S.C.

OTTAWA, 5th June, 1905

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the letter from Rev. Father Lacorre addressed to the Premier asking for a grant for an increased number of pupils, or a special grant to enable the Isle-a-la-Crosse school to put up a new building, I beg to say that at present the school receives a grant of $72.00 for each of 20 pupils, and in reply to a previous application for additional grant earners, Rev. Sister Thiffault was informed in September last that the Department regretted that no provision could be made for taking more pupils into this school.

It appears from Father Lacorre's letter that the present building, which has accommodation for 50 pupils, was under water owing to the flooding of the lake by heavy rains, and that the Grey Nuns who have had charge of the school are leaving in consequence. Bishop Pascal, who is now in France, is bringing out nuns to replace them, but a new building, the priest says, will be necessary. The Department is not responsible for the site chosen and we have no funds available for a contribution to the proposed new building. If it is decided to make a grant, provision would have to be made in the Supplementary Estimates. No special amount is asked for, but the erection of a new building in that locality would be expensive.

When the Indian Commissioner applied for an
increase in the number of pupils in 1903, he stated that the work done in this institution was worthy of encouragement, and the number of grant earners was then raised from 12 to 20.

We have very little information about this school, which is 80 miles from the nearest post-office and off the regular route of inspection, and I think this application could stand until the school policy of the Department is being dealt with.

Excellence,

Permettez-moi, sous le nom de missionnaire de M. D. du Rosier, d'implorer votre grâce. Je suis missionnaire français, âgé de 65 ans, et résidé depuis 34 ans dans ces froids régions de l'extrême Nord. Bien que fatigué et bien des privations ont été mes partages durant cette longue carrière. Mais une rude épreuve, survenue depuis peu, nous a réduit à la plus triste situation. En suite d'une inondation du lac de Croix, nos constructions en bois ont été tellement détruites, et notre champ de foins, (le seul produit que nous puissions cultiver dans cette région de table) tellement saccagé, que le tout n'est qu'un plan de ma rive. Nos pauvres familles et nos enfants souffrent tellement du froid dans leur demeure dépourvue, que c'est vraiment pitié de les entendre tous continuellement, quant à nous, bien et frais, nous n'avons l'autre abri provisoire qu'un mince hangar. Il faut dire que nous nous remettons à l'œuvre pour reconstruire la Mission et l'Ecole, sur un autre emplacement plus favorable. Mais ce travail entraîne de grands dépenses, et nous sommes à pauvres. Même pour l'entretien de nos enfants, nous n'avons guère que le pain que nous prenons nous-mêmes dans la dune.

Je vous supplie donc, Excellence, de mettre bien soin à notre aide, et de nous permettre de continuer notre fructueuse apostolat, comme en toutes missions, que nous avons toutes consacrées à notre foi. Elle sont vraiment catholiques, et confient volontiers leurs enfants à nos soins. Nous prions pour recevoir d'elle une bonne éducation. Déjà, votre gouvernement, si liberal, nous a donné des témoignages de sa sympathie, en nous accordant les subventions pour 20 enfants de nos Indiens. Mais nous ne avons plus de 10, et si nous resterions le permettant, le chiffre serait encore bien vite dépassé. Permettez-moi donc, à la veille de construire un nouvel établissement, plus moderne, plus conforme, dans la dimension et son aménagement, aux besoins du département des Écoles et aux besoins du district, permettez-moi, dit-je, Excellence, de solliciter de votre Grâce,

To His Excellency,

The Honorable Wilfrid Laurier,

Sir,

I am taking the liberty under the auspices of M.D. du Rosaire, to implore a favour of you. I am a French missionary, Oblat of M.J., and have lived for 34 years in these cold regions of the extreme north. Many fatigues and many privations have been my portion during this long career. But a severe trial, which has overtaken us recently, has reduced us to the saddest position. As a result of an inundation of Lake La Crosse, our wooden buildings have been so shaken, and our field of potatoes (the only product which we are able to cultivate in this sandy region) so destroyed, that the whole thing is little more than a ruin. Our poor sisters and our children suffer so much from cold in their badly constructed house, that it is really pitiable to hear them continually coughing; as for us fathers and brothers, we have no other provisional shelter than a poor shed. It is therefore necessary for us to get to work to rebuild the mission and the school, in another more favourable place. But this work entails great expense and we are so poor! Even for the support of our children we have little but the fish which we catch ourselves in the lake.

I therefore beg Your Excellency to kindly come to our aid.

Excellency,

Please forgive my coming to you again for charity in favor of my poor mission of l'Isle à la Grosse, which has been sadly tried by flood. The Indian Schools Department has granted us a few years ago subsidies for twenty children, but on account of the number of these children, Cris a Montagnais that these two tribes could supply and of the expenses needed for re-building the destroyed property, the help is very small and insufficient. Monsignor Pascal, Apostolic Vicar, has sent me in France for the purpose of getting help either by collections and appeals to the lay brothers to devote themselves to our work. I hope to find a little help in my own country, Brittany. But as regard collections, It must be renounced absolutely on account of spoliation and persecution to which Church in France is subjected, at present, so that I have no hope left for this dear mission, the first by its foundation, the mission of our late and regretted Lords Cahoe and Grondin, I have hope, I say, only in the favorable interest you have so far shown to our missions of the Northwest which soon will, no doubt, receive the treaty, will not fail to pay its debt of gratitude to you, Excellency, its debt of profound attachment and gratitude.

Please accept, Excellency, from me and from the communities under my charge, the expression of our respectful feelings.

A. Lecorre, Priest,
Asylum of Ste. Ann d'Auray (Morbihan)

Sir,

With the report enclosed I wish to submit to your attention a few remarks about our boarding school at Île à la Crosse, founded in 1869 consequently long before any other school in the present province of Saskatchewan and it was till 1897 kept solely by the Roman Catholic Mission. At this date the Rev. Father Rapet, superior of the mission and principal of the school made a request to the Dept. of Indian Affairs that the title of "boarding school" be given to this school, he also asked that the sum of $864.00 be given for the keep of a dozen children.

Six years later, upon new demands, to the same Dept., then under your able care, decided to raise the number of children receiving $72.00 each, to 20.

To-day I come again to ask you another favor, and permit me to say, to appeal to your love of justice in favor of our school and the people who devote their time and energy to its welfare.

We endeavour to give an education worthy of the name and we hope to find men in the Indian Dept. who are willing to help us and who are interested in spreading instruction and religious principles among the people of the North, which is the foundation of true civilisation, for this work we will ask your help, we have prepared all the material necessary for the construction of a larger school which will be better fitted for the needs of the time, and better situated than the old buildings that were old 40 years ago, we think it our duty to replace them and as they are not in the best place owing to the changes of time we have chosen a new site situated at the confluence the Castor, and Laplonge rivers about 30 miles from here.

Consequently we ask if the Dept. will please,
Ith—permit the transfer of the "Boarding school" from Ile à la Crosse to this new place.

2ndly, to raise the number of children supported from 20 to 30.

3rdly, to raise equally the contribution of each child from $72.00 to $100.00 right here it might be proper to say that our expenses in living are more than other schools of the same nature owing to our being far from a centre of population, and our nearest stations are Prince Albert and Duck Lake; and it costs us $5.00 per 100 pounds freight.

I also wish to call your attention to our wants for the school articles. My predecessor made application to the government for assistance in putting up the new building but the Dept. did not give any attention to his demand; all we ask now is that the Dept. give us the same favors as those accorded to other schools of this nature.

The land has not as yet been surveyed and we ask that about 200 acres be set aside for the new school, the land on the border of the Castor river in the ordinary prairie, and about the amount asked for has been already cleared and worked by us.

These are Hon. Sir the observations I wish to place before you, as well as the requests I wish to make.

Yours etc.

Principal

The Principal of the Isle a la Crosse Boarding school has applied for an increase in the grant. At present they are allowed $72 for each twenty boarders. He also asks that the number provided for be increased to thirty.

The Principal states that they are prepared to put up a new building at the confluence of the Cassia and Laplonge rivers, about 30 miles from the present location, and asks permission to transfer the Boarding school to this site. The land in this locality has not yet been surveyed, but they would like to have it set aside for school purposes, as they have already cleared and worked it.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 19th instant re matters concerning the old Isle a la Crosse Boarding School and must say that I know very little about the removal of this institution to some point south of its former situation, outside of press reports, which are not always very accurate.

The old site at the time it was selected, over half a century ago, may have been very suitable for missionary purposes, but the fixed population has scattered away and the roving population trades elsewhere.

As to "Castor" River mentioned, I beg to say that this is the French form of "Beaver" River. This will be found on any recent map running fairly from west to east in latitude $54^\circ$+ and turning towards the north at almost a square angle in longitude $107^\circ - 108^\circ$ until it meets what I take to be the La Plonge River, running out of the Lake of the same name in latitude $55^\circ$+.

I am sorry to say that I have nobody at hand to inform me of the nature of the country at the point selected, but I feel pretty sure that it could not be any worse than the old site, which, I believe, was not abandoned at an earlier date on account of the money expended there and also for sentimental reasons.

Sir:

The Isle a la Croix mission was founded about sixty-two years ago by Father Laflèche, who afterwards was a prominent figure in the Quebec hierarchy, and Brother Tache, who afterwards filled the See of St. Boniface. The church built by them was destroyed by fire and has been replaced by another.

The building next in importance is the school conducted by the Sisters. It shows marked evidence of age externally, but is cosy within, and the children whom I had the pleasure of meeting there, evidenced the kindly care and careful training of the devoted women who have gone out from the comforts of civilization to work for the betterment of the natives of the north. The priests' house is a small one. Its only door opens into a large room which occupies the greater part of the building and which is the common gathering place of the Indians and Halfbreeds who sit and smoke with an ease that seemed born of long habit of free intercourse with those who have undertaken the cure of their souls. The mission is about opposite the Company's post. It is close to the shore.

The site is rather flat and for miles on three sides stretches a bald prairie, though we were told that the mission when founded on the fringe of the forest. Whatever it may have been, it is no longer a desirable situation for a boarding school, and a new one has been erected at Rivers la Plonge, some thirty miles south of the mission.
The building is one hundred feet by sixty-two feet, and is two and a half stories high. It was being finished when I visited it. The site is a delightful one on a rising ground from the river which here breaks into a cataract that the Oblate Brothers have harnessed for power purposes. They cut the logs, and, with the harnessed river, sawed them into lumber, with which they built the school, a splendid monument to their mechanical skill, industry and devotion. When I was leaving Isle a la Crosse, the moving of the children from the old to the new institution had begun.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

It is not just and right that the Department should pay part of the expenses incurred for the accommodation of the numerous Indian children of the district. I renew, therefore, the application made by Bishop Pascal when he last charged of these matters, and sincerely hope that you will give your earnest attention to the matter.

I request also that the number of children receiving the government grants should be brought from 20, the present number, to 75 as there is ample room for that number and there are lots of children to be instructed and educated if the Government keeps the promises made to the Indians at the time they made their treaty.

I would add also your consideration of the following facts: The school is very near one hundred miles from Fort la Corne, the last point reached by any road, and from there all supplies have to be carried by boat in summer and by train in winter. Consequently one bag of flour costs at the school three times more than...
at Peace River or any other school in the province, consequently also
the grant which may be sufficient for schools on the railway line or near
civilized centres, is altogether insufficient for our faraway school, and I

Sir,

Allow me to ask your kind consideration for a letter I wrote today to the Hon. Secretary of Indian Affairs about our Indian School at Little Black River. I visited this school last August and came back from my trip north about the middle of September. If the officials of the Indian Dept. did not come across Bishop's letter, I have no reason to believe that they will take more notice of mine and therefore I take the liberty of writing you to bring yourself into the matter I wrote about. Our school will be, or rather is already a success, and happily the class of Indians we have to teach does not in any way resemble too many of our prairie Indians. They are good honest people trying their very best to profit by our advice and the white traders living amongst them readily acknowledge that they are worth the trouble we take to educate their children. We have gone to very great expense in order to build and equip the school and I confidently expect that the Survey Commission will give you a good report of what they saw on their visit to the school. Such an amount as all with our means alone, then Indians are under the care of the Government, and they have been promised that the said Government would provide them with schools conducted by their priests. I ask in my letter for what I consider to be just and reasonable, and if you consider the very great distance supplies have to be freighted, you will not find my request for the augmentation of the grant per capita out of reason. It is the only fair means to help us in the work we have undertaken for the benefit of your charges.

The request for the land may seem at first quite large, but you must consider...
That a great part of the land asked for is composed of muskegs, rocky ridges and a small part of cultivable land. It will take years to clear land enough for our fields and the artificial prairies made necessary by the frequent rise of the Beaver river which floods the whole low land for miles and miles. I do not think that the grant I ask of you will in any way be injurious to the settlement of this country which is not fit for farming or ranching. On the contrary our well and other improvements may induce a few settlers to take up land on the other side of the Beaver to assist members of our establishment.

In concluding this letter I wish in behalf of the Indians ask you to take steps to insure the enforcement of the law prohibiting the use of poison for killing game. A few white men have done much harm around here & la Cross in this way and the Indians complained of this before me and asked me to help them by laying their complaints before the authorities. It is also a well known fact that white hunters killed for the sake of the skin only more than one moon and left the whole carcass to rotten where the animal had been killed.

I hope Sir, that you will kindly settle up the different points of my letter and give us all the satisfaction you can.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

The Deputy Superintendent General,

The Rev. M. Grandin, of Edmonton, has written two letters to the Minister, dated the 10th inst., regarding needs of the Lao la Plonge school, which is the successor to the one formerly conducted at Isle a la Crose.

He asks that the Department give them a grant to recoup them for the outlay in the erection of the building; to increase the pupilage from 30 to 75; to increase the per capita grant from $73 to $100; to provide them with sufficient land for farming and grazing purposes; and to install an electric lighting plant.

They have put up a number of buildings, the main one being 100 ft. long by 52 ft. wide and two storeys high, costing about $10,000.00. Father Grandin does not state how much he expects the Department to contribute for this purpose, but as the Churches are in the habit of asking for one-half the cost of buildings from the Department, he would expect at least $5,000.00.

Of course, such extensive buildings would accommodate the increased number of pupils asked for, but to meet the outlay this would entail an increased grant an additional expenditure of $6,000.00 annually.

The question of land grant would have to be dealt with
with by the Department of the Interior. Father Grandin asks for about 4000 acres. He states that his reason for asking for this quantity of land is because they wish to protect their water power, as they have gone to great expense in damming the la Plonge river, where they have put up a saw and shingle mill and from which they derive their water supply for the school. This stream would furnish power for running an electric light plant, the cost of installing which would be close on $2,000, as a direct current generator with a capacity of 300 16- op. incandescent lamps; together with 300 sockets, 300 lamps, 300 resettes, 350 lbs. of wire, 3000 ft. of electric cordage, switches, cleats, tubes, voltmeter and ammeter would cost about $1200 F.O.B. Ottawa, to say nothing of freight and wages of an expert to place it in position.

The money needed to meet Father Grandin's application would amount to at least $13,000, without taking into account the grant of land asked for. This seems a large amount of money to spend for the purpose of educating nomadic Indians. The increase in the per capita grant from $72 to $100 is worthy of consideration, owing to the excessive cost of freighting in supplies.

On the same day that I received your letter of the 1st inst. I had one from the R.C. Agent telling me his yearly accounts and I see indeed that the charges mentioned in your letter were received by the Rev. Principal. I cannot explain how I misunderstood so completely the state of affairs at the school and I willingly apologize for the trouble of your unnecessary.

In my first letter of October 10th I asked the Indian Department to give to the school a certain amount of land that the staff may start some kind of a farm and that they may erect the house necessary for the cattle and horses of the school. There is one Father and three brothers working at the school and the school has granted the land as homesteads, but I am afraid, knowing the country, that one section would not be sufficient for the purposes of the school. Much of the country is not fit for farming and will never be, it is only here and there that one can find a piece of land that may be utilized. The hay crops are very often entirely flooded, and last fall we lost a quantity of hay that was carried away by a wave of the Beaver River. Moreover we have a fine new well on the La Plange creek and we wish to protect the work already done by obtaining from you the ownership of the land on both sides of said creek from La Plange to the Beaver River. The latter is four miles from the school and as there is no settlement around that part of the country, our claims would not interfere with the rights of any one, but would give us a variety that what we have done would remain undisturbed and encourage us to do more future work. We have installed a pump that supplies water to the school from the creek and you to request again to complete the works and buy the machinery necessary for that purpose. Now we would like to have electric lights in the school and if the...
were willing to supply the machinery, we could by machines do all the work required. I hope, Sir, that you will be able to help us in this matter which is very important now and it is so difficult to get safely so far such of railways or even common good roads.

I have a letter of the Dept. authorizing 30 children in the school from each district but I much suspect that there are already more than this number in the school; and that many more are waiting your permission to be received.

I hope that my claim for an augmentation of the parish, will be granted as the expenses for the maintenance of children at the Place are among the most burdensome than in any other school that I know of.

Thanking you for your answer and hoping that these demands will receive your kind consideration, I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

H. Baudin

Sir,

In answer to your letter of March 31st 1906, I beg to state that I wrote to the Principal of the St. Joseph's school, the numerous questions to be answered in order to obtain the privilege of using the water power in case he should presume to install an electric light plant in his school. But I must draw your attention to one of the points of my letter to which you do not give any answer. I was stating in this letter of mine that we had built up a school 100 feet by 50 feet above the river, and costing us about $10,000, without receiving any help from the Department. In all boarding schools built so far, it has been the practice of the Indian Department to grant a subsidy for the cost of the whole amount expended, but for a good share of such amount. I was asking the Department to do the same for our school and as I believe my request to be just and fair I take the liberty of renewing my demand today. Besides the building of the school we have at our expense dug a canal very near 1000 feet long and 2 feet deep to carry the creeks water to the school, put up a good dam and installed an automatic pump which will supply any amount of good and pure water for the use of the school. It seems to me that we deserve a substantial help from the Department and I hope that you will see your way to encourage us in our effort to make this Indian school one of the best in the country.

Sir:

I have the honour to report the death of an Indian girl named Aldina Kewaskunikere (Canoe Lake band) which took place at the Roman Catholic boarding school at Lac la Plonge on Sunday, 17th October, 1909, as a result of injuries from burns.

I understood from one of the brothers at the above school, that the girl (who was far gone in consumption) was playing around a burning rubbish heap, and her dress caught fire with the result that she was more or less burned about the legs, and that she died on the date above mentioned. The burning took place some few days previous to her death. Since speaking to the brother I have been informed that the children at the school were employed at the time of the burning in getting up potatoes, and that the fire was lighted at which to warm their hands.

I respectfully request that a copy of this report be forwarded to the Supt. General of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, and I would also respectfully suggest the stationing of an Indian Agent and a doctor at this place (Ile a la Crosse).

Dear Sir,

Last winter I informed the Department by letter, that the Indians of the District of Isle & La Crosse required their children to be instructed principally in French language, at the Lake La Plonge School.

The answer has been that the instruction be simply given in English. I then transmitted this decision to the Rev. Father Principal and order was given to the teacher to teach in English exclusively. Now during my visit at Isle & La Crosse in August last, the Chief accompanied by a large number of Indians addressed to me the following protest:

"If English only is to be taught, we will withdraw our children or at least we will never allow others to come. We want our children to learn a little English, and above all French."

I answered that the affair was not in my hands, but that it was relevant of the Department, and consequently that they should address all complaints to you. Together they decided to send you a letter concerning this matter. If they have not as yet done so, it is probably because they wish to have the consent of another Chief, absent at the time, and as you know communications are slow in those parts of the country."
I am in receipt of a letter from the Rev. Father Angel, Principal of the Lake La Plonge School, who says the following:

"As regards the school I am very much embarrassed. The Rev. Fathers at Isle à La Crosse and at Portage La Loche are unanimous in telling me that the Indians have in common accord decided to hold back their children from the School if French is not taught chiefly. What am I to do? I desire a decision without delay."

I therefore pray the Department to reconsider this question and to give the decision called for. Knowing the dispositions of those Indians, I believe it to be wiser to grant their request; for they will certainly keep back their children and the school will lack in recruits.

I am Sir,

Your humble servant,

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith my report on the Annuity Payments throughout Ile a La Crosse Agency, Treaty No. 10 for 1925.

At 3:30 P.M. the next day, we reached Beauval or La Plonge. We went ashore here and visited the boarding school. A reception was held for us by the staff and pupils, the latter singing songs of welcome for us. Some of the girls sang solos, which were rather nicely rendered. The boys executed some military exercises, which were well done. Their marching was perfect. After the reception I examined the work of the children in the class rooms. I found this work of a high standard especially in the upper grades. The blackboard work and oral arithmetic being good. The writing is very good. Reading is the weak point. The accent is very French and articulation indistinct, but this is offset to a certain extent by the excellency of the other work. Sister Adelin is in charge of the senior class room, while Sister Carrier teaches the juniors. Neither sister has a certificate, but are doing good work. Sister Adelin especially who has her classes well in hand and well disciplined. (There are 67 pupils in the school, but of this 67 only 23 are children of treaty Indians. The other 45 are half-breeds from Clear Lake, English River, Snake Lake, Portage la Loche and from around Beauval. It seems deplorable that this school should be filled with half-breeds when it could easily be filled with treaty Indian children from Canoe Lake, Clear Lake, Portage la Loche and English River Bands, all of whom are Roman Catholic.)

The school is kept very clean; the pupils well clothed and apparently well fed, as they all looked fat and healthy. The girls are taught to do housework, sewing, cooking, knitting etc. besides the class room work. The boys are taught farming, the care of stock, work around a saw mill. The saw mill is situated on the La Plonge River beside a waterfall which supplies the power. This fall drives the mill and matching machines. An extra flume is connected with a turbine wheel beneath a work shop, in which are installed, re sawing machines, planers, matchers, lathes, pumps and a dynamo. All this machinery is driven by water power. The school and all out buildings are lighted from this power, and all water used in the school and gardens is pumped from this work shop also. There is a farm of about forty acres under an oat and root crop. This crop was looking splendid at the time of my visit. The garden was also well advanced.
