SISTER LOST HER LIFE IN ATTEMPT TO RESCUE CHILDREN

Forty-six saved from inferno, most of them by nun who died trying to reach other helpless boys.

SASKATOON, Sask., Sept. 21.—A special dispatch to the Saskatoon Tribune from North Battleford states that the sister who lost her life along with 19 children in the burning of the Roman Catholic school at Beaulav, R.C. Institution on the north side of the province Monday night died in an attempt to save the children.

Commiss. Bock, Saskatchewan Provincial police, of North Battleford, 400 miles south of the scene of the tragedy, will go north Battleford today and will leave immediately by automobile. He will travel to Beaulav by canoe down the Beaver river. Dr. M. McMillan of Edmonton will accompany him as coroner. The two men cannot reach Beaulav before Saturday at the earliest.

The charred bodies of nineteen boys, ranging in age from seven to twelve years, and the remains of a heroic sister, rested tonight in an improvised morgue in the small hamlet of Beaulav, Sask., while investigators sped to the scene of one of the most tragic fire disasters in the history of this province.

TRAPPED IN DORMITORIES.

Details of the midnight fire which destroyed the Catholic school at the isolated village on Monday night are still being gathered. It is stated that the fire enveloped the structure so rapidly that the adult members of the mission were powerless to save the boys trapped in one of the dormitories. Twenty-three children were rescued from the flames, most of whom were led to safety by Sister Lee, who gave her own life in a valiant effort to reach the helpless boys.

The Sister Superior of the mission was the first to raise the alarm. Awakened by the roar of the flames and the crash of falling timbers she rushed to the alarm bell then ascended the central staircase and boys' dormitories where she called upon the panic-stricken occupants to escape by the stairs she had used. Unheeding, they crowded to the main stairway but here faced with a rush of flames which engulfed the floor below. Caught between two sheets of flame the boys then became panic-stricken. Scrambling up the corridor, they sought a way to safety, but most of them collapsed as the dense smoke and heat enveloped them. It was in this corridor and at the foot of the main staircase that all nineteen bodies were later located.

NUN AND NINETEEN CHILDREN PERISH IN MISSION FIRE:

Beaulav R.C. Institution on Lac La Plonge Destroyed.

Located in Isolated Section of N. Saskatchewan.

PRINCE ALBERT, Sask., Sept. 21—Nineteen children and Sister Lee were burned to death and a priest whose name has not been learned, was so seriously burned that he is expected to survive, when they slept when fire destroyed the isolated Catholic Mission on Lac La Plonge, Monday night, according to word brought by launch which made the 130-mile trip to Big River, Sask., today. Forty-five survivors were saved. The launch came out for supplies and clothing and those on board were able to give only meager details of the tragedy. Dr. A. Amos, Regina, who was sent to Lac La Plonge, six miles north of Lac La Plonge, to open a new Grey Nun's hospital at that place, hastened to the mission by airplane.

According to the fragmentary reports, the fire started in the attic in the boys' dormitory. The flames seized upon the dry frame structure and within a few minutes were devouring everything around the building.

Scene of Horror.

The eager flames and their reflection from the waters of the lake lit up a scene of indescribable horror. The children who made their way to safety by the blazing building huddled in the circle of light and heard the screams of those trapped in the flames. Here and there nothing could be done to help, as the furious heat prevented any attempt to enter the mission, and soon the structure was a mass of smoking ruins.

It is understood that all the children in the mission were Indians, but their names were not obtained.

Government officials and telegraph companies put forth every effort to get additional information of the tragedy today, but few details trickled out.

The Beaulav Mission is in charge of Father Lajauanesse, of the Oblate Fathers, who is assisted by Father Ancel and Father Adair, eight brothers of the order and eight sisters of the congregation. The heads of the mission are: Sister Superior Raymond, Sister Cartier, Sister Houné and others.

The mission is one of the oldest in the north. The buildings, a mixture of lumber constructed and fitted on the hot air principle, and the institution operated its own power and light plant. The fire was the third to occur within the last few years.

IDENTITY OF SISTER.

EDMONTON, Alta., Sept. 21—According to private advices received here, the Sister who died at Beaulav Mission was Sister Lee, a native of Northern Saskatchewan.

WAS LARGE FRAME BUILDING.

REGENA, Sask., Sept. 21—Hon. J. M. Ulrich, minister of Health for Saskatchewan, and Dr. M. M. Seymour, deputy minister, returned only yesterday afternoon from a visit paid at Beaulav. They attended to the vaccination and inoculation of the children.

Dr. Ulrich describes the school as a large frame building. It was a Federal government institution under the administration of the Grey Nuns.

Beaulav, Dr. Ulrich said, is the northernmost point in the north country of the Oblate Mission, and besides, the school there is a farm with several large buildings. It is centered in the midst of bush land, and the mission has a clearing of about 140 acres.

Efforts immediately make Beaulav their headquarters.

Indian children from practically all the north country attend school there. Dr. Ulrich declared the school had done fine work among its pupils and he was inexpressibly shocked at the news of the disaster.

The Indian schools of Canada and the Church among the Indians experienced last Monday night the 19th day of September 1927, the saddest accident in their history. The Department of Indian Affairs is anxious, I know, to have a detailed account of the incident.

1) Description of the School. The third floor contained two dormitories, one at each end of the house. The southern dormitory housed the boys and the northern, the girls. In the centre, at the top of the stairs, was a space occupied by the water tank and a storeroom. Two doors lead from this: one to the boys dormitory and one to the girls. That into the former room was always opened into the landing. Five staircases lead to the dormitories. One in the centre previously mentioned and two at the outer end of each dormitory. One of these was entirely outside the building with doors opening outwards. The other was just inside the wall arriving close to the outside door. Stairs, platforms and doors were all in good condition and the doors of boys dormitory were not locked according to Father Seguin.

2) Origin of the fire and its development. It began in the centre around the furnace in which a small fire was made about five o'clock P.M. The flames apparently spread south through the main floor corridor, all the doors of which must have been opened, and mounted to the boys dormitory by the nor-
At the same time, the flames mounted the main staircase to the third floor just outside the centre exit from the boys dormitory.

Apparently, Sister Lee, in charge of the boys, seeing the outside door barred by fire, tried to make any exit through the centre with the boys and again was met by flames. Thus they were trapped between two fires and all perished. The fire invaded the whole building in about three or four minutes. At first, the fire was confined to the centre and northern parts of the building, thus giving the girls a better chance to escape.

Activity of the staff. Sister Superior first heard the crashing about 11:30 P.M., she rushed down to ring the alarm bell, woke up all the sisters who rushed out in night attire and were immediately followed by a blast of smoke and flames. Sister Superior still clad in her night clothes, then proceeded by the outside stairway to the boys dormitory where she also gave the alarm. By this time, the smoke and flames had made an entrance to the second floor impossible from the south. Apparently, as stated above, the inmates of the boys dormitory wasted valuable time by trying to find, as they thought, a safer exit by the centre stairway at the bottom of which all remains except one were found.

Sister Superior cried fire from the gallery and this woke up the Fathers. Father Gagnon repeated the cry of fire and also rang an alarm bell in the Fathers house. I slipped my casebook on and rushed out in bare feet followed by Father Gagnon and Brother Macdonald. I noticed that that the south western corner of the school was all in flames and realizing that it was hopeless to attempt any rescue from there proceeded to the girls dormitory.
At the same time, Brother Beaudoin and others tried to extinguish the flames around the dormitory by use of the chemical fire extinguishers. It dampened the fire for an instant and at this time a great smoke arose, but again the flames burst forth and rapidly spread. The girls filed out, clad in night attire, in perfect order, many of the older ones carrying their small companions in their arms, thus saving their lives. I marveled at the cool calm way the children behaved. Many of them even carrying bedding and articles of clothing along with them. The sister in charge made sure that all girls were out of the building before leaving herself.

Then, Father Gagnon who had followed me passed into the dormitory now filled with dense smoke and attempted to reach the boys this way. While crossing the room, he heard a faint cry which was quickly drowned by the roar of the fire. I also heard this cry but nobody else did. It was the only cry heard, all being made so quick. Apparently the roar was due to the floor collapsing precipitating all the boys and the sisters to their death. Father Gagnon attempted to open the communicating door but fell suffocated by smoke. On the floor, the air was better and when I called to him, he was just able to answer: "I am lost, where are you?" I continued calling "Here, here" taking between each cry a breath of air outside the door. Father Gagnon guided by my voice was able to find the door and staggered just inside. I caught and pulled him out into the fresh air exhausted.

Realizing that the school was beyond saving and as the boys dormitory was completely engulfed in flame, we made an attempt to save the Fathers house and outbuildings. The distance between the school and the house is only about 20 yards but finally with combined help of the staff and bystanders (workmen attached to the mission).
and the mail carrier) using all available water the house and buildings were finally saved though badly scorched. The extinguishers were refilled and successfully used in this work. When the water tanks gone out water was carried by bucket from the river. Within about fifteen minutes from the time fire was first discovered, the walls of the school had fallen inward and nothing was left but a mass of burning ruins. The chapel burned last as it was on the back of the school. Father Gagnon seeing the danger to the warehouse containing provisions, etc., which was quite close to the chapel, proceeded to protect it from the flames. This was also saved. When all danger was passed, I gathered all the people into a group and recited prayers for the repose of the souls of the poor Indian children and the sister who had been so suddenly taken.

The survivors were later housed and fed in the Father's house where they are at the present time. Assistance was given by the neighbouring Indians when possible; clothes for the children and sisters were brought from the mission at Île-à-la-Crosse by Father Rossignol as speedily as possible.

4) Precautions taken against fire. As noted, we had five staircases in good repair, of which two were outside, one at each end of the school; chemical extinguishers in convenient places ready for immediate use; ladders from the ground to the top of the building at the chimney. The weather turning cold, Father Gagnon before using the furnace, closely inspected it and its surroundings to ascertain if all was in proper order and safe to light. Nothing was detected. The complete heating plant was in perfect order. This was three days previous to the fire. The same Father walked around the outside of the school at ten o'clock the night of the firesaying
his rosary and at that time did not notice any smoke or sign of fire.

If Sister Superior had not given the alarm, and acted as she did, in three or four minutes, all the inmates of the school probably would have perished. The absence of wind and the fact that the bush, houses and buildings were still damp from the heavy rains of the previous days assisted the firefighters in containing the fire to the one building.

I immediately summoned Dr. Amyot from Ile-à-la-Crosse who quickly arrived by a forestry aeroplane to attend the survivors. He reports that all are in good physical condition except a few minor burns and slight effects from smoke.

5) Losses: One sister; sister Lea. Nineteen boys from 7 years old up to twelve.

BEAUVAL MISSION FIRE

The jury in the Beauval Mission fire case here have exonerated everyone from blame in the matter, which is probably quite right so far as those directly in charge of the mission were concerned. The fact that Sister Lea lost her life in a heroic effort to save the children, and one of the men employed with the mission risked his life in similar effort is sufficient testimony to the fidelity of those in charge of the mission.

The loss however of nineteen children who were wards of the Government lost their lives in a fire that was only too likely under the conditions which should not have existed would warrant much stronger criticism than the lines of the jury "that the difficulties great buildings of this nature with proper equipment in case of fire." If it is worth while educating the Indians and congregating them in missions for that purpose, it is only fair that proper buildings be constructed and that the fire hazards be eliminated to the fullest possible extent. In our opinion the jury would have been fully justified in bringing in a verdict of criminal negligence against the Department of Indian Affairs, the guardians of these young Indians. The Department showed no negligence according to the implication contained in the verdict of the jury.

Following the Montreal theatre fire of last month the papers were filled with warnings and information of the activities of fire chiefs and others in regard to making safe all public buildings, but the surveillance soon ceased and it is doubtful if the lesson proved of lasting benefit.

Dear Sir:

In reference to your instructions to me to pay annuity and report on matters in Isle a la Crosse Agency, I have the honor to report as follows.

BEAUVAL SCHOOL

From here the party went to Big River where we received the camp equipment and, after repairing canoes, left for Beauval school on June 15th, where we arrived on Sunday afternoon, the 17th. This school is located at Lac la Plorge, and is in charge of Rev. Fr. Adam; the main building of this school was destroyed by fire on September 19th last, and the staff have been carrying on under difficulties ever since. They built a temporary house last fall which is used for all purposes from cooking to classroom work and is, of course, overcrowded, but the best that can be had until the new school is built. Two boys and 24 girl pupils are kept at present. The place is very clean and tidy. The classroom work of the pupils present is well up to the standard, and the children are well mannered, healthy and well clothed; 26 were in attendance at the time of my visit.

This school and mission is about 25 years old; there is a river through the property and the staff have harnessed the water power which they use to operate a saw-mill planer, run an electric light plant, and for all sort of purposes. They have a ram installed to supply water to the dwellings, school, barns, gardens etc.

About 65 cattle are kept here, and they had 18 cows milking at the time of my visit, so the pupils get all the milk they can use; they get the eggs from over 150 hens, so it can be seen they are well and correctly fed. There are 18 horses kept here to do the farm work in summer and haul freight in winter.

There was about 30 acres of the finest looking, clean, oat crop standing 9 inches high, and it will turn out well I imagine. Also a field of barley, seven acres of potatoes, two of beets, carrots, etc. There are 52 acres of crop and 18 acres of pasture here.

The saw mill was about to close down after having cut about 150,000 F.B.M. of lumber this spring. There are large hay flats near the school used for pasture and crop.

My long explanation of what is being done here by the staff, assisted by the Indian boy pupils, is to show that the latter are being taught how to make a living after they leave the school.

J. W. Waddy,
Paying Agent.

Cher Monsieur :

C'est aujourd'hui le triste anniversaire de l'incendie de l'Ecole de Beauval. Le souvenir de cette hécatombe est encore bien vivant dans nos coeurs, comme aussi dans le vôtre, je n'en doute pas. Nous pleurons les vingt victimes que cet incendie a couché prématurément dans la tombe et nous déplorons la destruction d'une bâtisse qui avait coûté tant de travail et de sacrifices aux missionnaires. La mort des premières est irréparable, mais la perte de l'école est chose réparable. Or c'est à ce sujet que je viens attirer votre attention. Le but de cette lettre est de solliciter le secours du Gouvernement pour faire sortir de ses gendres un monument que le zèle et la piété des missionnaires avaient élevé pour subvenir à l'instruction et à l'éducation des enfants indiens.

Tout d'abord, doit-on construire? Il me semble que poser cette question c'est la résoudre, car il est évident qu'il doit en être ainsi. L'Ecole de Beauval est une des plus anciennes de l'Ouest canadien. Il est vrai que ce n'est que vers 1905 qu'elle est devenue officiellement école indienne, subventionnée par le Gouvernement, mais elle existait depuis 1860 comme école de mission à l'Ile-à-la-Crosse. Il ne serait pas à l'honneur du Département de laisser disparaître une telle institution. Sa disparition laisserait tous les enfants indiens du grand district de l'Ile-à-la-Crosse dans l'impossibilité de se faire instruire, car il n'y a pas d'autre école pensée où ils pourraient aller, et les écoles du jour, on le sait, ne sont pas pratiques dans cette partie du pays. On peut affirmer, il me semble, qu'il ne serait pas équitable que le Département indien laissât laissât plus de cent cinquante enfants indiens sans aucune chance de se faire instruire.

Objecte-t-on que dans cette partie du pays, le sol n'est pas apte à la culture et ne permet pas aux anciens élèves de demander leurs moyens de subsistance à la terre? Non assurément. Tout d'abord, l'instruction n'est pas requise seulement pour pratiquer la culture. Il y a bien d'autres fonctions où l'instruction est utile, même nécessaire. Je connais bon nombre d'anciens élèves de nos écoles qui gagnent honnêtement leur vie grâce à leur instruction, comme employés des diverses Compagnies de traite des fourrures.
Actuellement, cette partie du pays se remplit de blancs peu scrupuleux et avides de lucratif. Comment nos indiens pourront-ils leur faire face s'il n'ont aucune instruction? Sans elle ils seront facilement victimes de la cupidité de ces avanturiers et étant dans l'impossibilité de subvenir à leurs propres besoins ils seront de plus en plus à la charge du Gouvernement.

À Beauval comme dans ses environs, l'agriculture n'est pas aussi facile que dans le sud de la Saskatchewan à cause de la forêt qui recouvre le sol. Tout de même l'expérience de plusieurs années prouve que la culture n'est pas impossible et qu'elle est même très rémunératrice. Ainsi cette année, on a, à la mission de Beauval, trente acres de belle avoine, cinq d'orge, sept de patates et deux de carottes, de betteraves et de choux de Siam. Il y a en plus dix-huit acres en pâturages comme aussi un grand jardin où poussent les légumes de toutes sortes. On y compte encore soixante-cinq bêtes à cornes dont dix-huit vaches à lait, cent-cinquante poules, quelques cochons et dix-huit chevaux de travail. Le climat y est également favorable; le blé comme l'avoine y mûrissent très bien tous les ans. Il est donc évident que la culture est possible à cet endroit, même qu'elle réussit très-bien.

Tout le monde prévoit que dans un avenir assez rapproché, les indiens auront à demander leur subsistance à la terre à cause du manque de poisson et de fourrures. Actuellement, la chose leur est, pour ainsi dire, impossible, car ils n'ont aucune notion du maniement d'une ferme. Mais quand les jeunes gens auront passé cinq à huit ans à l'école où ils auront tous les jours l'opportunité de travailler sur la ferme de l'école, ils deviendront familiers avec ce genre de travail, y prendront goût, et pour peu qu'on leur accorde l'assistance post-scolaire ils deviendront facilement fermiers. Leur avenir sera alors assuré. C'est un fait que les indiens du nord sont arriérés sur ceux du sud. Or ce n'est pas en les privant des bienfaits de l'école qu'ils pourront s'améliorer. De plus tous les districts du nord ont leurs écoles pensionnats, pourquoi celui de l'Ile-à-la-Crosse en serait-il privé?

Mais certains disent peut-être: "Si les autorités religieuses désirent une école qu'elles la construisent..." À cela je réponds que nous avons élevé à nos dépens l'école qui a été incendiée l'automne dernier, mais nous ne sommes pas disposés à recommencer. Quand même nous le voudrions, nous ne le pourrions pas, faute de ressources suffisantes. Le confort requis dans les écoles modernes est trop grand et trop coûteux pour que nous puissions affronter de telles dépenses. On n'en est plus aux temps héroïques où le pain n'apparaissait jamais sur la table et où l'invariable menu se composait de pémikan et de poisson. Il n'y a que le Gouvernement qui puisse faire face à une installation moderne. Celà ne veut pas dire que nous nous désistons de toute obligation, loin de là nous sommes prêts à y mettre du nôtre mais il faut que le Département fasse aussi sa grosse part. Déjà la nôtre est considérable. Nous avons à la
disposition de l'école une belle grande maison, bien aménagée et chauffée à la vapeur pour le personnel masculin et les grands garçons, deux grandes et magnifiques étables avec toutes les améliorations modernes, une pâcherie et un poulailler de toute première qualité; un beau grand hangar, une remise où se trouvent tous les instruments agricoles: charrues de toutes sortes, faucées, moissonneuse, machine à battre à vapeur, épin à vapeur, presse à foin, arrache-souche etc etc... Une digue en pierre jetée sur la rivière La-Plonge tout à côté de l'école fournit l'énergie nécessaire pour activer un moulin à scie où la machinerie au complet, permet de manufacturer le bois sur place. À proximité du moulin, s'élève une grande boutique et une forge munies d'outils et de machines. Dans cette boutique, une turbine à eau de moindre dimension que celle qui active le moulin et qui peut fonctionner tout l'hiver, met en mouvement une dynamo capable de fournir la lumière électrique à tout l'établissement. Un bélier hydraulique distribue, d'une manière très économique, l'eau aux maisons et aux étables. C'est là il me semble une part digne d'être appréciée.

Quelle sera maintenant la part du Gouvernement? Il me semble qu'après l'exposé de ces faits, elle ne manquera pas d'être grande et généreuse. Toutefois tout ce que nous demandons pour l'été prochain, c'est qu'un subside de $25,000.00 nous soit accordé afin de nous permettre de jeter de solides bases et de mettre en bonne voie de construction cette œuvre qui nous tient tant à cœur.

Avec l'espoir que mon humble requête recevra un accueil favorable, je demeure, cher Monsieur,

Votre tout dévoué,

+O. Charlebois, O.M.

Vicaire Apostolique du Keewatin.
This day is the sad anniversary of the fire that destroyed the Beauval school. The recollection of that holocaust is still living in our hearts as it is in yours. I have no doubt. We are mourning the twenty victims who were laid in their graves and we deplore the destruction of a building which had cost so much labour and sacrifice of our missionaries. The death of the victims is irremediable but the loss of the school can be restored. It is on this matter that I wish to draw your attention. The aim of my letter is to solicit the help of the Government to raise again from its ashes a monument which had been elevated by the zeal and piety of the missionaries, to provide for the tuition and education of the Indian children.

First of all should we rebuild? It seems to me that to bring up the question is to solve it; for it is evident that this should be done. The Beauval school is one of the oldest in the Canadian West. It is true that about 1905 it officially became an Indian school subsidized by the Government but it was in existence since 1860 as a mission school at l'Île-à-la-Crosse. It would not be of any credit to the Department to let an institution of this kind disappear. Its disappearance would leave all the children of the large district of l'Île-à-la-Crosse without the opportunity of obtaining any education as there is no other boarding school where they could go; and the day schools as it is well known, are not practical in this section of the country.

I may venture to say that it would not be equitable for the Department to leave more than 150 Indian children without any chance of being educated.

Would there be such objection raised that in this
part of the country the land is not suitable for agriculture and does not allow the graduated pupils to earn their living from the product of the soil? Surely not. First of all instruction is not given only for agriculture. There are many other activities in life where education is necessary. I know a large number of old pupils from our schools who earn their living very honorably on account of their education as employees of several fur trading companies.

At present this section of the country is filling with unscrupulous white people whose aim is gain. How will our Indians cope with the situation if they are uneducated? Without education they would be easily victimized by the greed of these adventurers and if they fall to a state where they will be unable to provide for their own subsistence they will then be more than ever a burden to the Department.

At Beauval and in the surroundings as well, agriculture is not so easy as it is in the South of Saskatchewan on account of the forests covering the ground. However the experience of several years proves that farming is possible and even profitable. For instance this year we have at the mission of Beauval, 30 acres of fine oats, five of barley, seven of potatoes and two of carrots, beets and siamese cabbages. There are 16 acres of pasture land and a large garden where vegetables of all kinds are grown. There are 65 cattle out of which we have 18 milk cows; 150 chicken, a few pigs and 18 draught horses. The climate is also favorable; wheat and oats ripen every year. It is therefore evident that farming is possible in this locality and that it is even successful.

Every one foresees that in the near future the Indians will have to turn to the soil to gain their living as a result of the depletion of the land of fur bearing animals and fish. At the present moment this is almost impossible to them, as they have no idea of the management of a farm. But after the young men will have followed the school for 5 to 8
years, where every day they will have the opportunity to work on the school farm, they will familiarize with this kind of work, will develop a taste for it, and if they are given any post-scolar help they will easily become successful farmers.

Their future will then be assured. It is a fact that the Indians of the North are not as far advanced as those from the South. It is not therefore by depriving them of the benefit of a school education that they will improve. Furthermore, all the districts in the North have their boarding schools, why then should Ile-à-la-Crosse be deprived of one?

It may be said that "If the religious authorities wish for a school they can build one"; to this I wish to say that we erected at our expense the school which was burnt last Fall, but we are not in a position to do it again. Even if we wanted to we could not on account of our lack of fund. The necessary comfort in a modern school is too large and costly for us to attempt to make such expenditure. We are no longer living the heroic time when bread was never served on the table and when the invariable menu was composed of pemikan and fish. Only the Government can defray the cost of a modern installation. This does not mean that we want to desist ourselves of all obligations, far from it we are ready to co-operate, but the Department must do its share. Ours is already very large. We have at the disposal of the school a fine large building well furnished and heated by steam for the male members of the staff and grown up boys. There are two large and magnificent stables with all the modern improvements, a piggery and a hen house all of the best quality; a large barn; a shed where the agricultural implements, plows of all kinds, mowers, harvesting machines; a steam threshing machine, a steam engine, a hay press, a stump lifting machine, etc., A stone dam across Laflange river, right next to the school supplies the necessary power to operate a saw mill with all its machinery, making it possible to manufacture lumber on
the spot. In the proximity of the mill there is a large shop and a smith's forge with tools and machinery. In the shop there is a smaller turbine than that supplying power to the mill, which can run all winter; it operates a dynamo of sufficient strength to furnish light to the whole establishment. A hydraulic pump distributes water in a very economical manner to the buildings and stables. This constitutes a share which should be appreciated.

What should be the share of the Government?

It seems to me that after submitting the facts it should be generously large. However all we ask for next summer is that a grant of $25,000.00 be given us to start the construction of an institution we have so much at heart.

Hoping that my humble request will be favorably received, I remain, Sir,

Yours devotedly,

(sgd) O. Charlebois, O.M.I.

Bishop of Keewatin.

Letter from Father Adam, Principal of the Indian School at Beauval, dated Jan. 6th 1929.

Re Admission of Half-breed children into the School.

--------

Letter from Mr. McLean, dated Dec. 17th, in which Father Adam is asked to follow closely the instructions given by the Department to his predecessor, Father Lajeunesse, concerning the admission of children to the Beauval School.

These instructions were:
(a) - That the children of half-breeds outside of the treaty should not be admitted to the School.
(b) - That such children, now in the school, should be dismissed as soon as possible.

Clause (a) has been strictly complied with since the above instructions were given.

Concerning clause (b) the following considerations are submitted to the Department:

1. The children of half-breeds outside of treaty who are now in the School were admitted therein by Father Lajeunesse legally and in good faith. Legally because such children were admitted in accordance with a circular from Mr. Scott dated Nov. 9th, 1922 in which it is stated that: "There is a departmental ruling to the effect that half-breed children living the Indian mode of life on a reserve are eligible for admission to the boarding school, &c."

In Good Faith, for, (i) on the admission sheets there was never the least attempt at misrepresentation; the children were set down for what they really were; (ii) children of treaty Indians were never refused admission into the School; (iii) children of half-breeds outside of treaty were admitted only in extreme cases; most of them were orphans.

Considering that the Department has knowingly and freely sanctioned the admission of the above-named children, it seems to have at the same time, and thereby, given to the School a moral pledge that the said children would be kept until they reached the age of 18. Had the principal been able to foresee that the children admitted would have to be dismissed in a couple of years, it is quite probable
that he would not have admitted them at all.

There are now in the School 5 children, all girls, whose parents are half-breeds outside of treaty. Six of these are orphans without father and mother.

What Father Adam proposes to do:

He will dismiss two of the children mentioned above during the course of the winter. They live at a post which is very distant from the School, but they will be sent there at the very first occasion available.

One has been placed as a maid-servant in the hospital at Ille-à-la-Crosse. Another will be 15 years of age soon and will be dismissed at the end of the year, or immediately if the Department requires it.

The four remaining children are orphan girls without parents and Father Adam is at a loss to know how he is to dispose of them. He will await the decision of the Department in the matter.

J.A. Lajeunesse.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to report as follows on my visit to the Beauval Indian Residential School on the 14th and 15th inst.

This school is under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church and the Principal is Rev. Fr. L.M. Adam. The school is located close to the Red Deer River about thirty-seven miles southeast of Isle a la Crosse. The main school building was burnt in 1927 and since then has been operated with small number of pupils present in a building close to the site of the old school. There are only 22 pupils present or in residence at the present time but a full staff of teachers is held in reserve pending the opening of the new school under construction. The expense of keeping a full staff on hand is considerable, but the Principal is well advised in doing so as to be ready with a capable staff when more are required.

I first inspected the work of the sewing class of twenty girls. They had knitted stockings, sweaters, mitts and caps; had made dresses, towels, underclothing and handkerchiefs etc.; embroidered numerous articles; could use the sewing machine very expertly. The teacher has also got them well started in basket making and weaving with cane; all the work is very neat and is of service. You shipped this school a lot of army hospital clothing and most of it has been remodelled into dresses and other articles by the pupils and staff. They would like more of it if it can be obtained.

The school class rooms were next examined and the pupils found to have made good progress since my last visit. They first had a singing class and the singing was in distinctly clear English, not mumbled or sung parrot fashion. The pupils are up to grade four and they can read in English quite without hesitation from the readers; they speak up in good manner; the spelling was in most cases correct; arithmetic was handled by the teacher announcing a problem after which the pupil would walk to the blackboard and work out the answer. Most of the problems were of practical nature and each one included addition, multiplication, division and subtraction, and in all cases the answer was correct and was worked out in bright honest fashion without any assistance from the teacher. The writing of the pupils is very good. As the children are of mixed Cree and Chipewyan parentage they have to speak English as the common language.

The dormitories were examined and found to be well ventilated, neat and had good exits in case of fire. The pupils use the outside stairs at all times so would be familiar with their use if trouble occurred.

The dormitories were rather low in the ceiling and the air space is not very large but this cannot be helped under present conditions.

The kitchen is large and the food given to the pupils is cereals, milk, eggs, all classes of common vegetables, beef, moose meat, fish, bread and butter, and plenty of each.

Every pupil has a separate plot of garden as their own, besides they have to work in the community garden; they also look after the hens, pigs, live stock etc under the supervision of the staff. All pupils were well clothed.

The farm which surrounds the school was next visited. Since last year ten more acres of land have been cleared of large trees, roots grubbed out, and all placed under cultivation. There are now eighty acres of crop as follows:

Last season the crop gave a harvest as follows:

Hay wild and cultivated gave 350 tons in all.

Threshing is all done by the staff.

The oat crop would have been much larger but the migrating blackbirds held their annual convention in the oat field and fed off the ripe crop.

The soil is very sandy loam but is fertile; just now all grain is ahead of that close to Regina. The potatoes are above the ground and were receiving the first cultivation. No noxious weeds are to be found here, and the early frosts do not occur on the plateau where the crops are grown. There are 68 cattle here of which twenty are being milked, they are in good condition; they have sixteen horses with three foals; one hundred hens with droves of young chickens; there are eleven pigs on the farm. The machinery is all housed and the place is a model farm.

The saw mill is run by water power and 50,000 f.b.m. of spruce and cedar cut this spring. At the time of my visit they were sawing birch for the floors of the new school.

The power plant run by water power was burnt last spring. Since the forest fires came through the north the water storage is not reliable but the Principal is putting a dam at the head of the La Plonge River to hold back the water in the La Plonge Lake for use during low water periods.

The water for all the buildings, gardens, barns etc is pumped by a ram; it is the most economical system imaginable and needs little attention.

The hay lands near the school are not surveyed yet but I understand that the Department has reserved some land for the school until surveyed. This is something that should not be overlooked at the time Saskatchewan gets their natural resources.

Last year I mentioned the matter of having the Dgt of Public Works clear the rocks from the rapids in the Cowan or Crooked River as the school
3.

Beauval School.

transports their supplies over the river route in summer. The Department took this matter up with the Dept of Public Works and last fall the work was done. A little fixing is still required I understand and more work to be done on the rapids in the Beaver River to make them safe.

Dr. Amyot came to the school at the time of my visit and he vaccinated the pupils. The health of the children is very good though one has T.B. and one epilepsy.

The staff here does not need much mention as when you read this report you can see they must be first class to get such results.

You probably are familiar with the arrangements regards building the new school here, I understand it is being built by the church authorities under arrangement with the Department. The rear wing of the new school is to be built this year; all material for the heating, electric fixtures, water system is on hand, also the sand, gravel, cement, lime, lumber etc. The basement is excavated, footings of cement in, forms up for the basement walls. The whole school is to have solid brick walls, all the brick is being made within one hundred yards of the school site. Last winter a brick making machine was brought in from Prince Albert with a steam engine to supply the power. The staff used over 40,000 f.b.m. of lumber to construct the drying racks for the bricks, making sheds etc., and they have the plant in running order now. In the few days it has been operating they have made 75,000 bricks and they were turning out thirty bricks a minute when I was there; on Friday they made over 13,000. After the brick dries for a week a kiln is made and the brick burnt for three days. It is expected that 800,000 will be required. A first class bookkeeper is on the job and he keeps track of every item entering into the construction of the school, keeps the time of the men etc. He was watching the cost of the brick making very closely, and including overhead, cost of machines transport of same etc., time of expert brick maker, steam engineer and others who has been down to $20.00 per thousand and is trying to cut this down.

I may have missed out some things that should be in this report, but if any come to mind later I will include it in my final report on the Isle a la Crosse district.

Your obedient servant,

Paying Agent.

Pursuant to our conversation this morning, I write to inform you that the Department would like to have a report concerning the progress at the Besual Indian Residential School. Your intimation, that His Lordship Bishop Charlebois was hoping to admit pupils in January, comes as a surprise. The last information on our files suggests that the building was ready for the roof in October and that it was not the intention to do the interior finishing this year.

To plaster and finish the building and to have it ready for pupils should not be hurried, as it would be unsafe to have children sleeping in dormitories unless everything had been thoroughly dried out. Further, there is the matter of proper furnishing. As His Lordship understands, the Department has no funds to assist this year, and, before we can consider per capita grant, it will be necessary to have a full report concerning the preparations that are being made.
